High-quality afterschool programming during childhood promotes long-term adult mental health
Background
High-quality afterschool programming in children has been found to improve standardized test scores, dropout rates, and college attendance. The APPLE (Afterschool Programming for Psychiatric Long-term Endpoints) study seeks to examine the effect of such programs on long-term adult mental health.
Design, Setting, and Participants
Socioeconomically disadvantaged children ages 5–10 were recruited for this study. Participants with a history of intellectual/developmental disability or existing psychiatric illness were excluded. Eligible families were identified by screening government social service agencies in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and of all qualified families who were invited to participate in free afterschool enrichment activities for their children, 320 children were enrolled. The socioeconomic characteristics of study participants were found to be similar to those of the population being studied.
160 children were randomly assigned to free afterschool enrichment activities and 160 to a waiting list that served as a control; the parents of 12 children declined participation after their children were randomly assigned to the control group. Of the 83 children participating in the study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group.
Interventions
The intervention involved free afterschool programming for the first three years of the study. The programming lasted three hours per day and was held five days per week, consisting of an hour of creative problem-based math/reading instruction supplemented with two hours of music, art, and athletic group activities. Children in the control group were placed on the waiting list for the intervention.
Main Outcomes and Measures
Data on the incidence of common DSM 5-validated mental health conditions was collected at the study's 20-year follow-up evaluation and confirmed by chart review.

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination at a clinic for low-income residents. Although her son's elementary school offers free afterschool programming, her son has not been interested in attending. The son's maternal grandmother has schizophrenia. The mother is inquiring about the benefits of afterschool programming and asks for the physician's input. Based on the study results, which of the following statements best addresses the mother's question?

choices.text: High-quality afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing ADHD risk in adulthood than major depressive disorder risk.
The patient's family history of psychiatric illness prevents conclusions from being drawn from the study.
High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with a decreased bipolar disorder risk in adulthood.
High-quality afterschool programming should be free of charge for low-income children to improve adult mental health.
High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with decreased ADHD risk in adulthood.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The relative risk for the development of major depressive disorder among those in the afterschool programming group is 0.69, i.e., the investigated intervention produces a 31% risk reduction compared to the control treatment. The risk ratio for the development of ADHD among those in the afterschool programming group is 0.80, which means that the investigated intervention produces a 20% risk reduction compared to the control treatment. This indicates that afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing the risk of depression (31%) than of ADHD (20%).

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient has a strong family history of psychiatric disorder, his family history does not have an effect on the ability to draw conclusions from the study about a population. The abstract notes that the analysis adjusted for family history of income and psychiatric illness, suggesting that the researchers did not draw any conclusions about the effect of family history of mental illness (or interaction between family history and afterschool programming).

C) INCORRECT:

Although at first glance it may appear that children who receive afterschool programming may have a decreased risk of developing bipolar disorder (with a relative risk of 0.64), this finding was not statistically significant because the p-value is 0.34 and the confidence interval includes 1.0. This suggests that the observed difference is likely due to random error.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a policymaker may use the findings of this study to make an argument for increasing access to high-quality afterschool programming, this conclusion cannot be drawn from the study.

E) CORRECT:

The relative risk is a statistical measure used in clinical trials to compare the effect of an intervention on an outcome between two groups over time. A relative risk >1 indicates increased risk, and a relative risk <1 indicates decreased risk in the intervention group compared to the control group. For example, in a clinical trial comparing a new treatment to a placebo, a relative risk of 0.80 for a particular outcome suggests that the risk of experiencing the outcome is 20% (1-0.80) lower in the treatment group compared to the group receiving the placebo.
questions.hint: The abstract describes a randomized, controlled trial (RCT). Results from RCTs only apply to individuals with baseline and clinical characteristics similar to those of the population enrolled in the study and may not be generalizable to other populations. With this in mind, take a look at the relative risk and p-values in the table.

The APPLE study investigators are currently preparing for a 30-year follow-up evaluation. They are curious about the number of participants who will partake in follow-up interviews. The investigators noted that of the 83 participants who participated in APPLE study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group. This finding raises concerns for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Volunteer bias may be present at the recruitment stage of a study if individuals who opt to participate are different from those who choose not to participate. In this study, the researchers report the socioeconomic characteristics of the participants as similar, which means that volunteer bias is not a concern. Also, since volunteer bias pertains to conditions at the beginning of a study, it would not explain the discrepancy in follow-up rates between the intervention group and the control group here.

B) INCORRECT:

Lead-time bias is a concern with screening interventions but is not relevant in this study. Lead-time bias occurs when a screening intervention appears to prolong survival when it has only really resulted in an earlier diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

In a randomized controlled trial such as this one, randomization is done shortly after enrollment in the study. Randomization should result in treatment and control groups that are roughly equal in baseline characteristics to avoid confounding factors. A difference in the size of groups is not indicative of an error in randomization.

D) INCORRECT:

Allocation bias occurs when there are systematic differences between treatment and control groups. However, allocation bias occurs during group assignment at the beginning of a study, not during follow-up. Furthermore, the participants of this study were randomized to either the treatment or the control group, which makes allocation bias unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Loss to follow-up may cause attrition bias if the remaining participants differ significantly from those lost to follow-up, especially if the reason for the dropout is related to the outcome. In this case, the participants in the control group may have been more likely to be lost to follow-up, assuming they did not feel as committed to the study as those who received free afterschool programming. However, if the participants in the control group who remained in the study had a higher incidence of mental health disorders than those lost to follow-up (e.g., because those with mental health disorders in the control were more motivated to present for follow-up), using the data could lead the researchers to overestimate the risk of mental health disorders among those in the control group.

F) INCORRECT:

Loss to follow-up may have caused the remaining sample size to be too small and therefore reduced the statistical power of the study. However, an inadequate sample size would not explain the discrepancy observed between the number of participants in the treatment and control group lost to follow-up.

G) INCORRECT:

Reporting bias occurs when participants cannot or do not accurately report exposure or outcomes due to attitudes, perceptions, or beliefs. For example, a participant might be reluctant to report a history of sexually transmitted infections to a medical researcher. Reporting bias is not a concern here, as the type of exposure (afterschool programming) and outcomes were confirmed by the researchers via chart review. Moreover, the discrepancy between the original participants and the remaining participants in the groups would not be a cause of reporting bias.
questions.hint: Longitudinal studies with a large number of participants lost to follow-up are prone to this type of selection bias.

A 63-year-old HIV-positive man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and was started on cART therapy. He tells the physician that he has been having difficulty adhering to his medication regimen. He has been unemployed for the past couple of years and relies on unemployment benefits to cover the costs of daily living. His father died of lymphoma at the age of 60 years. He had recently heard about the results of the study featured in the abstract and wants more information about his risk of developing DLBCL. Based on the study, which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a similar profile as this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a positive family history in comparison to patients without a family history of cancer is 1.35, suggesting a 35% increased risk of developing DLBCL in patients with a positive family history. However, the p-value of 0.08 is higher than the conventional p-value cutoff point of 0.05, and the confidence interval of 0.93–1.43 includes 1.0, indicating that there is no statistically significant difference in DLBCL risk based on family history of cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in male patients in comparison to female patients is 1.08. This suggests an 8% increased risk of developing DLBCL in male patients compared to female patients. Although this finding is statistically significant (p = 0.02), another factor is associated with an even higher risk of developing DLBCL.

C) CORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with high adherence to cART in comparison to patients with low adherence to cART is 0.69. From this, you can calculate a 31% decreased risk of DLBCL in patients with high adherence to cART compared to patients with low adherence to cART. The relative risk of developing DLBCL among low adherence patients compared to high adherence patients would be 1/0.69 ≈ 1.45, corresponding to a 45% increased risk. The p-value for this relative risk is 0.03, meaning there is a statistically significant relationship between cART adherence and development of DLBCL.

D) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL among HIV-positive patients with an annual income between $30,000 and $90,000 and above $90,000 compared to below $30,000 is 0.87 and 0.88, respectively, indicating a decreased risk. The relative risk of developing DLBCL among patients with a yearly income below $30,000 (compared to between $30,000 and $90,000) is 1/0.87 ≅ 1.15, corresponding to a 15% increased risk. Though this finding is statistically significant (p = 0.04), another factor is associated with an even higher risk of developing DLBCL.

E) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients ≥ 55 years of age compared to patients < 55 years is 1.21, with a p-value of 0.11, indicating that there is no statistically significant increased risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients 55 years or older compared to patients younger than 55.
questions.hint: The abstract describes a retrospective cohort study. As a measure of the probability that observed results occurred by chance, p-values help determine the statistical significance of a relationship between two variables (e.g., a p-value of 0.05 indicates the probability of seeing the observed results by chance is 5%, assuming the null hypothesis is true). The magnitude of relative risk (not the p-value), however, is a measure of how strongly a risk factor is associated with a given outcome.

The authors of the study have decided to conduct a follow-up analysis of their data. They decide to stratify their results by CD4+ T-lymphocyte count at the time of diagnosis. Among patients with CD4+ cell counts below 200/mm3, cART adherence was a significant predictor of DLBCL risk (RR = 0.52, p = 0.01). However, among patients with CD4+ cell counts above 200/mm3, no relationship was found between DLBCL risk and cART adherence (RR = 0.96, p = 0.36). Which of the following explains the difference observed between the two strata?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Study generalizability is important for clinicians, as they must be able to discern whether a given study is applicable to their patient population. When a study is generalizable, it means that the results can be reasonably applied to populations beyond the target population to which the researchers initially sought to apply their findings. The phenomenon described above (differences in CD4+ cell count strata) is not related to generalizability.

B) INCORRECT:

In this case, the researchers used a stratified analysis to analyze the data, but this should not be confused with stratified sampling, which is part of the process of study design (not analysis).

C) INCORRECT:

Random error refers to unpredictable variations in measurement (or in the study population) that have no net effect on the relationship of interest but do lower the overall precision of the measures being studied. There is always some degree of random error in any study, but the described phenomenon (differences between the two CD4+ cell count strata) is not related to random error.

D) INCORRECT:

Confounding occurs when a third variable associated with both the exposure and the outcome creates a spurious association. If CD4+ cell count was a confounder in this case, the apparent relationship between cART adherence and DLBCL risk would disappear once the data was stratified by the confounder (i.e., it would be the same for both CD4+ cell count < 200/mm3 and CD4+ cell count > 200/mm3 groups).

E) INCORRECT:

A systematic error in the collection or analysis of data is known as a bias. If there was a bias in this case, there would be a difference in the quality of the data collected among the different groups. Although there could be significant systematic error in the design of this study, the described phenomenon (differences between the two CD4+ cell count strata) is not related to systematic error.

F) CORRECT:

Effect modification occurs when the magnitude of the relationship between the exposure and the outcome of interest is modified by a third variable. In this case, the association between the exposure (cART) and the outcome (DLBCL risk) is modified by a third variable (CD4 count). Consequently, stratification of the patients by CD4+ cell count reveals that the relationship between cART adherence and DLBCL risk is present for CD4+ cell count < 200/mm3 but not CD4+ cell count > 200/mm3. In other words, low CD4 count acts as an effect modifier, as it increases the risk of DLBCL in patients with poor cART adherence.

Effect modification is often confused with confounding. These two concepts can be differentiated by performing a stratified analysis: when the population is stratified according to a factor that is thought to be a confounder or effect modifier, different results will be seen if it is a confounder (no significant difference between strata) or if it is an effect modifier (significant difference between the strata).
questions.hint: In the crude analysis, high cART adherence was associated with a decreased risk of developing DLBCL. After stratification of the data for CD4+ cell counts at time of diagnosis, this association is only seen in patients with low CD4+ cell counts, while the association can no longer be found in patients with high CD4+ cell counts. Therefore, the impact of cART adherence appears to be affected by CD4+ cell count.

questions.text: A patient with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and a long history of alcohol use disorder and chronic hepatitis C has been using the mTOR inhibitor metalimus 100 mg for cancer treatment. Her cancer has shown a partial response. She also has a history of hypertension and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic retinopathy. Current medications include enalapril and insulin. She asks her oncologist and hepatologist if she could try Noxbinle (tumorolimus) for its purported survival benefit in treating HCC. Based on the data provided in the drug advertisement, which of the following responses is most accurate?

choices.text: "You are not a good candidate for Noxbinle because of your history of hypertension."
"Your history of diabetes may disqualify you from taking Noxbinle."
"You should start Noxbinle 50 mg because it has a survival benefit relative to your current medication."
"You should start Noxbinle 100 mg because it has a survival benefit relative to your current medication."
"You should start taking Noxbinle 50 mg because your history of alcohol use disorder and hepatitis C disqualifies you from taking a higher dosage."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The only statistically significant difference in adverse events between Noxbinle and Metalimus were seen in nephrotoxicity, impaired wound healing, hyperglycemia, and new infections (page 2). The advertisement does not report any cardiovascular adverse events. Consequently, the patient's history of hypertension is not a contraindication to Noxbinle.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a partial response to Metalimus without any reported side effects. The adverse events profile of Noxbinle on page 2 shows that almost 60% of patients receiving Noxbinle 100 mg develop hyperglycemia. Given this patient's history of poorly controlled diabetes, she may not be a good candidate for Noxbinle 100 mg. Although this difference in risk is only statistically significant for the 100 mg dosage, the advertisement also states that there is no survival benefit for lower dosages (page 1). Consequently, she should not receive Noxbinle 25 mg or 50 mg either.

C) INCORRECT:

The Kaplan-Meier survival plots on page 1 show a survival benefit for Noxbinle relative to Metalimus specifically for the 100 mg dosage. The advertisement states that there is no survival benefit for lower dosages relative to Metalimus 100 mg.

D) INCORRECT:

Although there is a survival benefit for patients who received Noxbinle 100 mg relative to Metalimus 100 mg, Noxbinle 100 mg is associated with a risk of serious adverse events that could affect this patient. Given the patient's medical history, she should not receive Noxbinle 100 mg due to safety concerns.

E) INCORRECT:

As the Kaplan-Meier survival plots on page 1 show, there was a survival benefit for Noxbinle 100 mg relative to Metalimus 100 mg, but there was no survival benefit for lower Noxbinle dosages relative to Metalimus.
questions.hint: Note the adverse events associated with Noxbinle as well as the dose that has been demonstrated to show a survival benefit relative to Metalimus.

Which of the following aspects of the results best supports a causal relationship between a history of DKA and 30-day readmission risk for DKA?

choices.text: Confidence intervals that do not cross 1.0

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The p-value is a measure of statistical significance, but it has no bearing on causality. One of the criteria for causality is strength of association, which refers to the magnitude of the study's outcome measure (relative risk or odds ratio, depending on the study design), not to the p-value.

B) INCORRECT:

The confidence interval gives the estimated range of values that is 95% likely to include the unknown “true” value in the study population. In this study, the confidence intervals for the relative risk values do not cross 1.0. This implies that there are statistically significant differences between the risk of readmission in patients with no history of DKA and the risk of readmission in patients with a history of DKA. This implies statistical significance but has no bearing on causality.

C) INCORRECT:

This is not a case-control study but rather a prospective cohort study. In a case-control study, the cases of an outcome of interest would first be selected, followed by suitable controls. The measure would be reported as an odds ratio, not relative risk. This is because, in a case-control study, actual risk cannot be estimated because a smaller number of controls and cases selected from the population are being studied rather than an entire population. In this prospective cohort study, 587 patients with recent admissions for DKA were followed and 100 cases and 487 controls were identified over time.

D) INCORRECT:

High odds ratio is incorrect because this study is a prospective cohort study, which uses relative risk as its measure of association rather than the odds ratio, which would be used in a case-control study. Actual risk (AR) cannot be estimated in a case-control study because a smaller number of controls and cases selected from the population are being studied rather than an entire population.

E) CORRECT:

The relative risk (RR) of readmission increases as the number of previous episodes of DKA increases, which means that there is a dose-response gradient. Increased amounts of exposure (in this case, prior episodes of DKA) leading to an increased risk of the outcome (in this case, readmission) is one of the criteria required to establish causality in epidemiological studies. Dose-response relationships are quite common in the epidemiologic literature. Other examples include the relationship between the amount of tobacco smoked and mortality from lung cancer, an incremental increases in blood pressure or left ventricle hypertrophy correlating with increased myocardial infarction risk, and an incremental increases in clozapine doses correlating with increased risk of seizures in patients with schizophrenia.
questions.hint: Some of the key criteria for causality include: (a) exposure preceding the outcome, (b) strength of association, (c) increased amounts of exposure leading to increased risk, (d) consistent results when replicated in different settings, (e) a plausible explanation.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is diagnosed with a rare subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis. During the diagnostic workup, she was found to have an ovarian teratoma. Her physician is curious whether ovarian teratoma is a risk factor for the development of anti-NMDA encephalitis. A causal relationship between this subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis and ovarian teratomas is suspected. The physician aims to identify patients with anti-NMDA encephalitis and subsequently evaluate them for the presence or a history of ovarian teratomas. Which of the following types of study design would be the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cross-sectional study would determine the prevalence of teratomas and anti-NMDA encephalitis at a specific point in time, but would not allow to draw a conclusion on chronological correlations (e.g., show that ovarian teratoma precedes anti-NMDA encephalitis).

B) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study would follow a large group of individuals over a period of time until they developed anti-NMDA encephalitis. As the subject of investigation here is an uncommon subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis, such a study would be costly and time-consuming.

C) INCORRECT:

A case series describes the clinical course of similar cases but does not allow drawing conclusions about causal relationships. At best, a hypothesis can be suggested based on several observed cases. Moreover, a case series would be very susceptible to selection bias because there are no comparator groups.

D) CORRECT:

Case-control studies are ideal to study conditions like uncommon subtypes of anti-NMDA encephalitis because they are the most economical way to study an outcome that is rare or has a long latency period and its associated risk factors. The comparison to a control group without anti-NMDA encephalitis helps determine the presence of risk factors that might be associated with the disease. To assess the strength of association between a risk factor and disease, the odds ratio is reported. Unlike cohort studies, case-control studies identify patients with or without the suspected outcome first (here: anti-NMDA encephalitis) and then evaluate the prevalence of the risk factor (here: ovarian teratomas) in each group retrospectively.

questions.text: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the total number of cases of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia in the United States using a national health survey of a nationally representative sample of US citizens conducted in 2012. The investigators ultimately found that a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection is associated with syphilis. This study is best described as which of the following?

In a meta-analysis, data from multiple studies is pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies and/or common effects among studies. The research group here conducted a single study.

questions.text: A research group designs a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. By reviewing medical records, the investigators identify a group of patients who were active cocaine users and did not have a history of syphilis as of one year ago. Another group of patients with no history of cocaine use and no history of syphilis infection as of one year ago is also identified. The researchers examine the medical records to determine whether the patients who were actively using cocaine were more likely to have developed syphilis over a 6-month period. The study ultimately finds that the rate of syphilis was 30% higher in patients who actively used cocaine compared to patients who had never used cocaine. This study is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study starts with identifying individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (e.g., cocaine use). However, in a prospective cohort study, participants are monitored for development of the outcome of interest (e.g., syphilis) for a fixed period of time after the start of the study, whereas in this example, data was collected from past medical records.

Using a prospective cohort study to research the relationship between cocaine use and syphilis infection would be time-consuming and, more importantly, ethically questionable.

B) INCORRECT:

In a metaanalysis, data from multiple studies is pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies between and/or common effects among studies. Here, the research group conducted a single study.

C) INCORRECT:

An ecological study is an observational study in which aggregate data collected at the population level (e.g., the population of different countries, cities, or socioeconomic groups) is assessed for exposures and/or outcomes. For instance, rather than collecting data from individual patients on cocaine use and history of syphilis infection, an ecological study might involve the collection of data from individual cities or communities.

D) INCORRECT:

A case series is a quantitative compilation of similar individual cases and does not allow conclusions about causal relationships to be drawn. At best, a hypothesis might be suggested based on several observed cases. In a case series, there are no comparison groups, which means that relative risks cannot be determined.

E) INCORRECT:

In a single-blind clinical trial, only the researchers know who is in the control or intervention arm of the study. This study was of an observational nature and did not involve the administration or testing of an intervention.

F) INCORRECT:

In a double-blind clinical trial, neither the researcher nor the study participants know who is in the control or intervention arm of the study. This study was of an observational nature and did not involve the administration or testing of an intervention.

Because the researchers followed individual patients with a certain trait (cocaine use) to determine if they had developed syphilis via chart review (i.e., retrospectively), they conducted a retrospective cohort study. This type of study begins with the selection of individuals who are determined to have either been exposed or not exposed to a risk factor of interest based on chart review. Individuals are then assessed retrospectively to see if they have or have not developed a certain disease or outcome. Retrospective cohort studies are time-saving and relatively inexpensive, as they involve the analysis of data that has already been collected. Cohort studies are well suited to determining the incidence of a disease and allow for the relative risk (RR) of developing a disease of interest to be calculated. questions.text: A group of gastroenterologists is concerned about low colonoscopy screening rates in their region. They decide to implement a free patient navigation program to encourage more individuals to obtain colonoscopies in accordance with US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) guidelines. Individuals were recruited at a community center and randomly assigned into two groups. The first group was enrolled in a patient navigation program and attended monthly meetings, where they were given regular reminders that their adherence to screening guidelines was being evaluated. The second group did not participate in the patient navigation program. Colonoscopy rates were assessed via chart review and showed that 90% of participants in the first group and 34% of people in the second group adhered to screening guidelines. Which of the following most likely contributed to the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Confirmation bias is the tendency of researchers to preferentially include or exclude results that support a given hypothesis. In this case, colonoscopy screening rates were assessed via chart review, and there is no indication that the researchers preferentially included or excluded data. Confirmation bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

B) INCORRECT:

Reporting bias refers to the selective disclosure or suppression of information that is sometimes related to stigma and prevailing social attitudes (e.g., past medical history, sexual partners, drug use). In this study, colonoscopy screening rates were assessed via chart review. Reporting bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

C) CORRECT:

The Hawthorne effect, commonly seen in behavioral studies, is the tendency of subjects to modify their behavior when they know they are being observed.

The first group in the study was given regular evaluation reminders, which likely accounts for their greater adherence to screening guidelines, as compared to the second group. If this study's researchers did not consider the role of the Hawthorne effect, they could have overestimated the success of the patient navigation program. Although there are methods for reducing the Hawthorne effect, such as withholding the aim of a study from its subjects and/or concealing the fact that they are being monitored, these strategies are not considered ethical. Conducting a study over a prolonged period of time can make subjects accustomed to being studied and is therefore an ethical strategy for reducing the Hawthorne effect.

High degrees of random errors, biases (e.g., Hawthorne effect), and confounding variables can limit the validity (i.e., accuracy) of a study.

D) INCORRECT:

Berkson bias is a type of selection bias that occurs when study populations are drawn from the population of hospitalized patients, which typically has different exposures and health outcomes compared to the general population. The groups involved in this study were both recruited from community centers. Berkson bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

E) INCORRECT:

Sampling bias occurs when certain individuals are more likely to be selected for a study group, resulting in a nonrandomized sample. Because the selected population is not representative of the target population, sampling bias can limit the validity (i.e., accuracy) of a study. In this study, all participants were recruited from one community center and randomly assigned into two groups. Sampling bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

F) INCORRECT:

Recall bias occurs when awareness of a condition by subjects changes their recall of related risk factors. It is common in retrospective studies. For example, a patient who has been diagnosed with cancer may have more complete recollection of possible exposures (e.g., missed preventive health screenings, occupational exposures) than a patient who has not been diagnosed with cancer. In this case, colonoscopy screening rates were assessed via chart review. Recall bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.
questions.hint: The frequent reminders given to participants in the first group likely influenced their behavior.

questions.text: A prospective cohort study was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) and surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) for treatment of aortic stenosis in adults 65 years of age and older. Three hundred patients who received TAVR and another 300 patients who received SAVR were followed for 5 years and monitored for cardiovascular symptoms and all-cause mortality. The study found that patients who received TAVR had a higher risk of death at the end of a 5-year follow-up period (HR = 1.21, p < 0.001). Later, the researchers performed a subgroup analysis by adjusting their data for ejection fraction. After the researchers compared risk of death between the TAVR and SAVR groups among patients of the same ejection fraction, they found that TAVR was no longer associated with a higher risk of death. They concluded that ejection fraction was a potential confounding variable. Which of the following statements would be most supportive of this conclusion?

choices.text: The prevalence of low ejection fraction is higher in the TAVR group
Low ejection fraction causes increased risk of death and decreased likelihood of receiving TAVR
The increase in risk of death conferred by TAVR is higher in patients with low ejection fraction
TAVR correlates with increased risk of death, but the magnitude of effect differs based on ejection fraction
Ejection fraction influences both probability of receiving TAVR and risk of death
Patients who receive TAVR and SAVR have similar ejection fractions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Differences in the prevalence of low ejection fraction between the TAVR and SAVR groups is not sufficient for ejection fraction to be considered a confounder — additional criteria must be met. By itself, differences in the prevalence of low ejection fraction between the two groups would indicate failure of randomization (in randomized control trials) or a selection bias.

B) INCORRECT:

If low ejection fraction caused an increased risk of death and decreased likelihood of receiving TAVR, crude analysis would have shown that patients who received TAVR had a lower (rather than higher) risk of death at the end of the follow-up period. Furthermore, causality cannot be inferred from this study and is not a prerequisite of a variable to qualify as a confounder.

C) INCORRECT:

This is a description of effect modification, a scenario in which having a low ejection fraction modifies (increases) the association between TAVR and risk of death. However, the researchers found no association between TAVR and higher risk of death once patients were stratified by ejection fraction.

D) INCORRECT:

This is a description of effect modification, a scenario in which having a low ejection fraction modifies (increases) the association between TAVR and risk of death. However, the researchers found no association between TAVR and higher risk of death once patients were stratified by ejection fraction.

E) CORRECT:

For ejection fraction to be a confounder, it must be related to both the exposure (here: having undergone TAVR) and the outcome (here: risk of death). In this example, the TAVR group likely had more patients with lower ejection fraction, who were at increased risk of death, than the SAVR group. In the crude analysis, this unmeasured variable (ejection fraction) makes it appear as if there was a relationship between TAVR and risk of death, when in reality the association disappears once you stratify patients by their ejection fraction.

F) INCORRECT:

If patients who receive TAVR and SAVR had similar ejection fractions, then ejection fraction would not meet the criteria for being a confounder variable.
questions.hint: A confounding variable can suggest a causal association of the outcome with the independent variable when, in fact, there is none.

questions.text: A gastroenterology fellow is interested in the relationship between smoking and the incidence of Barrett esophagus. At a departmental grand rounds she recently attended, one of the presenters claimed that smokers are only at increased risk for Barrett esophagus in the presence of acid reflux. She decides to design a retrospective cohort study to investigate the association between smoking and Barrett esophagus. After comparing 400 smokers to 400 non-smokers identified via chart review, she finds that smokers were at increased risk of Barrett esophagus at the end of a 10-year follow-up period (RR = 1.82, p < 0.001). Among patients with a history of acid reflux, there was no relationship between smoking and Barrett esophagus (p = 0.52). Likewise, no relationship was found between smoking and Barrett esophagus among patients without a history of acid reflux (p = 0.48). The relative risk value of 1.82 in this study is best explained by which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The p-value < 0.05 (here: p < 0.001) indicates that the likelihood that the association between smoking and Barrett esophagus is just due to chance or random error is smaller than 5%. However, after looking at another risk factor (acid reflux), the significant association between smoking and Barrett esophagus disappears, indicating a different kind of error.

B) INCORRECT:

Effect modification refers to a phenomenon in which the magnitude of the effect of an exposure on the incidence of disease is influenced by a third factor. For instance, the grand rounds presentation that the gastroenterology fellow attended suggests effect modification (“smokers are only at increased risk for Barrett esophagus in the presence of acid reflux”). If a statistically significant relationship existed between smoking and Barrett esophagus in patients with acid reflux, but the relationship did not hold in patients without acid reflux, this would be an example of effect modification. Instead, the relationship between smoking and Barrett esophagus is no longer statistically significant after adjusting for acid reflux.

C) CORRECT:

The results of this study are likely due to confounding. The correlation between smoking and Barrett esophagus is no longer statistically significant after stratification (controlling for acid reflux). Acid reflux is a confounder because it affects both the dependent variable/outcome (Barrett esophagus) and independent variable/exposure to a risk factor (smoking). Rather than a true association existing between smoking and Barrett esophagus, the results of this study suggest that the increased prevalence of acid reflux among smokers may explain the apparent association between smoking and Barrett esophagus in the unadjusted analysis. To minimize confounding during study design, stratification, randomization, and/or matching can be used. Good study design includes anticipating potential confounders.

D) INCORRECT:

It is certainly possible that the two groups in this study are not comparable because of selection bias. However, this would not explain why the significant association between smoking and Barrett esophagus disappeared when acid reflux was factored out.

E) INCORRECT:

Stratification is a method of study design used to prevent confounding. The population is first divided/stratified by a particular characteristic (i.e., a possible confounding variable) and then randomized. However, this approach does not explain why the relationship between the variables (smoking and Barrett esophagus) does not hold when a third variable (acid reflux) is examined.

F) INCORRECT:

In epidemiology, matching is a method of study design used to prevent confounding. However, this approach does not explain why the relationship between the variables (smoking and Barrett esophagus) does not hold when a third variable (acid reflux) is examined.
questions.hint: The relationship between smoking and Barrett esophagus changed after stratified analysis.

questions.text: A resident in the department of obstetrics and gynecology is reading about a randomized clinical trial from the late 1990s that was conducted to compare breast cancer mortality risk, disease localization, and tumor size in women who were randomized to groups receiving either annual mammograms starting at age 40 or annual mammograms starting at age 50. One of the tables in the study compares the two experimental groups with regard to socioeconomic demographics (e.g., age, income), medical conditions at the time of recruitment, and family history of breast cancer. The purpose of this table is most likely to evaluate which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Statistical power is the probability that the study will detect a statistically significant difference between the two experimental groups if one truly exists. It is not related to the table mentioned above.

B) INCORRECT:

Observer bias occurs when the investigator's knowledge or expectations influence the measurement of a variable or classification of subjects (e.g., as cases or noncases). Observer bias can be controlled with blinding. The table mentioned above is not directly related to observer bias. It might, however, be helpful for detecting selection bias.

C) INCORRECT:

Confounding is a type of systematic error that occurs when a third variable distorts the relationship between the exposure and the outcome of interest. Although it is related to confounding, the table in question does not directly evaluate whether confounding is taking place. Tables that directly evaluate confounding would show the outcomes of interest stratified by a given variable (e.g., socioeconomic status).

D) INCORRECT:

The replicability of a study is its ability to yield the same results if repeated in the future. The table above comparing the two experimental groups would not allow any conclusions to be drawn about replicability.

E) CORRECT:

Randomization is a central component of clinical trials. Unlike other methods of assigning cases and controls (e.g., restriction, matching, or stratified analysis), which rely on the investigator's knowledge of possible confounders, randomization can control for both known and unknown confounders. In order to show that randomization was performed successfully, most clinical studies include a table of patient characteristics that compares the different groups in order to show that possible confounders (socioeconomic status, demographics, etc.) are distributed approximately equally between the two groups.

F) INCORRECT:

Effect modification occurs when the magnitude of the relationship between the exposure and the outcome of interest is modified by a third variable. In order to evaluate for effect modification, the investigator would need to stratify the data by a third variable.
questions.hint: The two groups should ideally be very similar with regard to baseline characteristics related to socioeconomic demographics, medical conditions, and family history.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after an episode of cyanosis and muscle hypotonia that resolved after 2 minutes. Diagnostic evaluation fails to discover an exact etiology of the boy's symptoms and the episode is classified as a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE). The risk profile for BRUE in infants remains largely unknown. The pediatrician who saw the boy in the emergency department is trying to identify risk factors for BRUE. She is aware of several confounders, including age, socioeconomic background, and family history of medical illness. She recruits 75 infants under 1 year of age with BRUE and 75 infants without BRUE of the same age, socioeconomic background, and family history of medical illness. She then compares the two groups with regard to history of feeding problems and history of recent upper respiratory infection. Which of the following methods was conducted to control confounding bias in the study?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stratified analysis involves assessing the relationship between exposure and outcome in subgroups of the study population. The technique described above involves a sampling method rather than a method of data analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

While increasing the sample size of a study would increase its statistical power, it would not help to control confounding bias.

C) INCORRECT:

Blinding is a practice used to decrease the likelihood of bias, e.g., when investigators are blinded to which patients receive treatment versus placebo, or when patients are blinded to whether they are receiving treatment or placebo. The technique described above is not related to blinding, and blinding does not decrease confounding bias.

D) INCORRECT:

Restriction is a technique used to control confounding factors. It involves limiting the study population to patients that meet certain criteria (e.g., if the gender is a potential confounder, the investigator could allow only females to join the study population). Restriction limits generalizability and makes obtaining a sufficiently large sample size more difficult. This technique is not what is described in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Randomization is a method to prevent confounding that involves randomly assigning study participants to either the control or the experimental group. In the study described above, researchers defined the study cases based on an outcome that had already occurred (75 infants under 6 months of age with BRUE). No randomization has taken place.

F) CORRECT:

Matching is a statistical technique commonly used in case-control studies. By matching cases and controls based on potential confounders, this technique may help detect exposures (history of feeding problems, history of URI) that are relevant to the outcome of interest (BRUE). Matching does not completely eliminate confounding and may in fact introduce confounding if the investigators match by factors that are not matched in the source population. Matching may also introduce a bias by rendering the controls and the cases more similar to each other not only with regard to the factor the investigators seek to match but also for the exposure under investigation.
questions.hint: In this case-control study, the two groups were selected in a way that ensured potential confounders (age, socioeconomic background, and family history of medical illness) were distributed similarly.
