questions.text: A group of investigators conduct a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a new medication in the treatment of infectious mononucleosis. They enroll 3143 patients between the ages of 18 and 30 years who presented with mononucleosis-like illness and had a positive Monospot test. These patients are randomized to receive either the new drug or placebo for a period of one week. The primary endpoint of the trial is the time to resolution of symptoms from the onset of therapy and the secondary endpoint is the splenic volume as measured by ultrasonography one month after initiating therapy. At the end of the study, the mean differences of endpoint measures in each arm are determined and evaluated using t-statistics. For analysis, the investigators decide to exclude patients from both arms who did not adhere to the treatment protocol or dropped out of the study. When compared to an analysis that includes the nonadherent patients and dropouts from both study arms, the analysis performed by the investigators is most likely to have which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Despite a slight reduction in sample size, a PP analysis has a lower, not higher, risk of type 2 error compared to ITT analysis because PP analysis tends to overestimate the effect of the studied treatment. This also means that a PP analysis has a higher risk of type 1 error compared to ITT analysis.

B) CORRECT:

In a PP analysis, the evaluation of the effect of treatment assumes optimal trial conditions (i.e., an ideal scenario in which all patients receive and complete the treatment regimen they were assigned). In a real clinical scenario, however, patients may be nonadherent to treatment or lost to follow-up. This means that a PP analysis tends to overestimate the difference between outcomes in the treatment and placebo groups, which results in larger effect size (i.e., greater strength of association). Moreover, PP analysis increases the risk of biases (e.g., selection bias, confounding bias) because the original randomization of the trial is lost. On the other hand, an ITT analysis results in a smaller effect size (i.e., avoids overestimation of the new intervention's effect), greater generalizability (external validity) of results, and preserves randomization, which decreases the risk of bias.

An as-treated analysis (sometimes considered a subtype of PP analysis) evaluates patients according to the intervention they actually received, no matter which intervention they were originally assigned. This type of analysis is primarily used to assess the side effects of interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

When compared to ITT analysis, a PP analysis has less, not more, external validity (generalizability). A PP analysis is used to evaluate the treatment effect in an ideal scenario, in which all patients received and completed the treatment regimen by the end of the trial, rather than a scenario that more closely resembles a true clinical setting, where nonadherence is common (as in an ITT analysis).

D) INCORRECT:

When compared to ITT analysis, PP analysis reduces the degree of randomization, which normally results in groups with equal distributions of known and unknown confounders. The risk of bias (e.g., selection bias, confounding bias) thereby increases due to potential nonrandom nonadherence. Therefore, the risk of confounding is higher, not lower, in a PP analysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Lead time is often discussed in the context of a screening test for a chronic disease in which the studied outcome is survival. Since earlier diagnosis does not necessarily result in increased survival, the lead time may result in bias (i.e., lead time bias). In this scenario, the lead time is irrelevant because the study focuses on the efficacy of a new medication and not on a diagnostic test.
questions.hint: When analyzing data from a randomized controlled trial, the two main ways of dealing with study protocol violations (e.g., dropouts, nonadherence) are intention-to-treat analysis (ITT analysis), which includes all subjects (once randomized, always analyzed), and per-protocol analysis (PP analysis), which only includes subjects who adhered to the study protocol.

questions.text: A group of physicians from different specialties in the greater Phoenix, Arizona, area meet at a regional conference to discuss the application of evidence-based medicine in their respective clinics. On day 1 of the conference, the group is randomly split up into two subgroups of equal size. Every physician receives a questionnaire. The first subgroup receives questionnaires that assess the knowledge transfer of evidence-based medicine. The second subgroup receives questionnaires that explore the strategic approaches for the application of evidence-based medicine in the physicians' clinics. Both questionnaires contain a set of 10 questions. The physicians respond to each question by writing out short answers in a comment field. On day 2 of the conference, the replies to the questionnaires are anonymized and discussed within the subgroups. On day 3, both subgroups present their key takeaways. After the conference, an article with a summary of the findings is published in a national journal and the physicians decide to repeat the conference after 1 year to evaluate for changes over time. This study design is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ecological studies are observational descriptive studies that assess the prevalence of an exposure and/or outcome on a population or group level. These studies can be conducted with or without statistical analysis. The study in this scenario gathers data on an individual level rather than on a group level, so the data is not representative of a population.

B) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies are observational analytical studies that use statistical analysis, a quantitative research design. These studies retrospectively compare the exposure status (e.g., a risk factor) of individuals (i.e., cases) with a certain outcome (e.g., a disease) to the exposure status of a group of similar individuals without the outcome (i.e., controls). Although the physicians were split into subgroups in this scenario, the results of the groups were not compared and no statistical analysis was performed.

C) CORRECT:

Qualitative studies involve the collection and analysis of nonnumerical data obtained by certain methods, such as observations, interviews, and questionnaires with open-ended questions, that aim to describe and provide a deeper understanding of concepts and phenomena. The collected data is usually organized, reviewed, and explored for patterns, from which hypotheses or theories can be inductively developed. Common qualitative research approaches include grounded theory, ethnography, phenomenology, action research, and case studies. As opposed to quantitative research, qualitative research does not run statistical analysis of the collected data nor test hypotheses.

D) INCORRECT:

Cohort studies are observational, analytical studies that use statistical analysis, a quantitative research design. In these studies, two groups, one with a certain exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and one without, are monitored over time to determine whether the exposure is associated with a certain outcome (e.g., a disease). No statistical analysis was performed in this scenario, and the physicians were not observed over time.

E) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled studies are experimental studies that use statistical analysis to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population (i.e., a quantitative research design). In these studies, participants are randomly allocated as either treatment or control subjects. Although the physicians in this scenario are randomly split into subgroups, the results of the groups are not compared and the data is not statistically analyzed.
questions.hint: This study collects data with a free text field questionnaire and does not analyze the data through statistical methods.

questions.text: An ophthalmological research group decides to design a randomized, nonblinded, controlled trial to investigate the effect of meditation on subretinal fluid volume in patients with central serous chorioretinopathy. A statistician performs a sample size calculation. Two hundred men between 30 and 50 years of age with central serous chorioretinopathy need to be recruited and randomized to receive either routine care or meditation training with routine care for 6 months. The primary endpoint of the trial is the decrease in subretinal fluid measured with optical coherence tomography after 2, 4, and 6 months. The study protocol is reviewed and approved by an institutional review board. An ophthalmologist unaffiliated with the research group learns about the planned study from an online registry of clinical trials for participant recruitment. She recommends lowering the inclusion criteria for participants to 25 years of age because she recently read an article on the increasing incidence of serous chorioretinopathy in younger men. The research group agrees and decides to adjust the study protocol accordingly. Before continuing with the recruitment of additional study participants, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the lead physician-investigator?

choices.text: Include a secondary outcome measure in the informed consent form
Disenroll participants who have already been recruited
Submit a protocol amendment to the Institutional Review Board
Consult the Office for Human Research Protections

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Changes in the recruitment protocol (e.g., inclusion or exclusion criteria) should be communicated to current and prospective participants and must be implemented in the informed consent form. However, secondary outcome measures are typically part of the study protocol rather than the informed consent form. Moreover, changes in the inclusion criteria do not automatically necessitate a change in the outcome measures and aim of the study.

B) INCORRECT:

Participants who have already been recruited should be informed about the change in inclusion criteria and asked if they still want to participate in the trial. However, they do not need to be automatically disenrolled.

C) INCORRECT:

A research group may change study protocols during a trial for practical (e.g., personnel changes) and/or scientific reasons (e.g., changes in inclusion or exclusion criteria). To ensure safety, any changes to the protocol must be communicated to the relevant parties and approved by the appropriate organization.

D) CORRECT:

Any changes to an approved research protocol (e.g., including a patient population that was previously excluded from the study) must be submitted to and evaluated by an institutional review board (IRB). An IRB is a committee responsible for conducting initial and ongoing reviews and providing oversight for research activities involving human subjects. Even minor changes, such as lowering the inclusion criteria for participants to 25 years of age, should be communicated to and approved by the IRB.

Human research that is performed or supported by a federal department or agency in the United States must be in accordance with the Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects (i.e., the Common Rule). Examples of studies that do not require IRB review include service surveys, interviews about products or policies, educational tests, and secondary research involving publicly available identifiable private information (e.g., labor statistics).

E) INCORRECT:

The Office for Human Research Protection (OHRP) oversees and provides guidance on biomedical and behavioral research involving human subjects. Reasons to consult the OHRP include risk to participants and noncompliance with the requirements of the institutional review board. Lowering the inclusion criteria to 25 years of age is not a reason to directly consult the OHRP.
questions.hint: A clinical trial involving human subjects needs to be reviewed and approved before initiating any research activity to ensure safety and compliance with medical ethics.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up visit 8 months after undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Medical history is otherwise remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has been on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with clopidogrel and aspirin since TAVR. Other medications include lisinopril and metformin. The patient feels well but is concerned about the number of pills she is taking. She asks about the benefit of taking “two blood clot pills” and wants to know whether she can discontinue one of them. The physician informs the patient that one important indication for antiplatelet therapy after TAVR is the risk of stroke. The physician reviews a recent metaanalysis comparing the effects of single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) to DAPT on the risk of disabling ischemic stroke 6–12 months after TAVR. The graph shows the results of the study. Based on the graph, which of the following conclusions about the metaanalysis is most appropriate?

choices.text: The results indicate publication bias and should not be used to make a clinical decision
The sample sizes of the individual studies were too small to compare the overall risks of ischemic stroke
Ischemic stroke was more common in patients receiving DAPT than in patients receiving SAPT
None of the included studies showed a statistically significant increase in risk of ischemic stroke of SAPT compared to DAPT
Patients on SAPT appeared to have no statistically significant difference in the risk of ischemic stroke compared to patients on DAPT

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Publication bias occurs when the findings of a study affect the likelihood of its publication, typically causing an imbalance toward the publication of positive results. In a metaanalysis, publication bias can be evaluated with a funnel plot and certain statistical tests (e.g., Begg's and Egger's tests). The graph in this scenario is a forest plot that summarizes the relative risk of ischemic stroke in the included studies and does not contain information about publication bias.

B) INCORRECT:

In a forest plot, the sample size of each study is typically represented by the size of its corresponding square; the larger the sample size, the larger the square. Additionally, the sample sizes of individual studies are taken into account when calculating the pooled result (e.g., relative risk), which is represented by the diamond. The graph does not provide enough information on whether the sample sizes of the individual studies were too small to be compared.

C) INCORRECT:

The mean value (i.e., horizontal line) of the summary of all studies (i.e., the diamond) is > 1. This means that the relative risk (RR) of ischemic stroke 6–12 months after TAVR in patients on SAPT compared to DAPT is > 1. Although more patients on SAPT had an ischemic stroke, the difference was not statistically significant because the confidence interval included the null value.

D) INCORRECT:

In a forest plot, the horizontal line of each study represents the width of the confidence interval (CI). A horizontal line crossing the middle vertical line (i.e., the line of null effect) indicates that the CI includes the null value (a RR of 1 in this scenario) and that the result of the study is not statistically significant. There are two studies (B and F) in this metaanalysis for which the CI does not include the null value, indicating statistically significant results. Study B reports a statistically significant RR of ∼ 1.5 in patients who received SAPT compared to those who received DAPT, i.e., an increase in the risk of ischemic stroke.

E) CORRECT:

In this forest plot, the left column lists the included studies (A–F). The next column shows the primary outcome measure that is being compared between the studies, which is the relative risk (RR) of ischemic stroke in patients receiving SAPT versus DAPT 6–12 months after TAVR. The central vertical line on the x-axis represents the point of null effect (a RR of 1 in this scenario).

The results of each study are represented as squares and vertical and horizontal lines. The vertical line at the center of each square represents the point estimate of the effect of the intervention in the respective study, and the horizontal line of each square represents the confidence interval (CI) of the results (typically 95%). The area of each square is proportional to the weight that the corresponding study is given in the overall metaanalysis (e.g., based on sample size and/or statistical power). The larger the square, the more weight the result of the individual study carries.

The diamond at the bottom of the plot represents the combined results of all studies; its midpoint corresponds to the point estimate of the summary result, and its width reflects the CI.

Because the CI of the summary (i.e., diamond) in this forest plot crosses the vertical line of no effect (i.e., RR = 1), there is no statistically significant difference in the relative risk of ischemic stroke between patients on SAPT and those on DAPT in this study.
questions.hint: The graph shown is a forest plot that summarizes the findings of a metaanalysis. Squares and horizontal lines represent the results from individual studies, and the combined results are represented by a diamond.

questions.text:
A phase 2 multicenter, double-blind randomized superiority trial is performed to compare the efficacy of a new mood-stabilizing drug to lithium for reducing the risk of acute manic episodes in patients with bipolar disorder. The investigators plan to enroll 300 individuals with bipolar disorder over one year and assign them to receive either the new drug or lithium for 2 years. An interim analysis performed by the data monitoring committee 6 months after the start of the study reveals that several patients in the trial developed myocardial infarction. The results of the interim analysis for 187 participants over a 4-month period are shown:



New drug (n = 93)
Lithium (n = 94)
Relative risk (95% CI)



Incidence of a manic episode
6.4%
14.9%
0.43 (0.17, 1.07)


Incidence of myocardial infarction
4.3%
1.1%
3.90 (0.46, 35.49)



The dropout rate at the time of the interim analysis is negligible. No events of myocardial infarction were reported during phase 0 and phase 1 trials of the new drug. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial recommendation by the data monitoring committee to the principal investigator?

choices.text: Discontinue the trial because of futility
Continue the trial but inform unaffected and new participants about the risk of myocardial infarction
Continue the trial because the results are not statistically significant
Discontinue the trial until the reasons for myocardial infarction in the participants are clear
Continue the trial but exclude participants with additional risk factors for myocardial infarction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A trial may be discontinued if it is shown to be futile (i.e., unable to achieve its objectives) because of a poor enrollment rate, higher than expected dropout rate, or clearly inferior treatment efficacy. However, in this scenario, enrollment rates are acceptable (187 of 300 planned participants have already been recruited in the first 6 months), dropout rates are negligible, and the new drug does not show an inferior efficacy compared to lithium. A different recommendation is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

If UAEs occur during a trial, it may be necessary to provide additional information both to current and new participants as part of the informed consent process. However, in this scenario, a different initial step is needed to determine whether the UAE is related to the trial.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither result of the interim analysis is statistically significant because the 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of the relative risks cross the null value of one. Continuing the trial as planned with more participants would narrow the CIs and likely result in statistical significance. However, for UAEs (especially serious ones, such as myocardial infarction), the lack of statistical significance in an interim analysis is not a reason to continue the trial.

For expected adverse events, stopping rules, which take statistical significance and other factors into account, can help determine whether to continue a trial.

D) CORRECT:

Every trial requires a monitoring plan (e.g., interim analysis by a data monitoring committee) to ensure participant safety and scientific merit. Ongoing trials are discontinued when there is evidence of futility, safety concerns, or early evidence of clear benefit. A UAE, especially if it is serious (e.g., myocardial infarction), should result in temporary discontinuation of the clinical trial (even if the risk is not statistically significant on the interim analysis) until the reasons for the event are determined.

If the adverse event is determined to be related to the trial, it may be necessary to modify the research protocol (e.g., by altering the exclusion or inclusion criteria, changing the dosing, increasing the monitoring frequency) to minimize the risk to participants. Protocol modifications need approval from the institutional review board and often require reconfirming informed consent for ongoing participation. The trial should be terminated if it is not feasible to minimize risk to an acceptable level.

E) INCORRECT:

If a UAE is shown to be related to research and restricting certain participants from the trial can reduce risk to an acceptable level, a change in the exclusion criteria (with approval from the institutional review board) may be appropriate. However, a different initial step is needed to determine whether the UAE is related to the trial in this scenario.
questions.hint: Unexpected adverse events (UAEs) typically occur in phase 2 and phase 3 trials because these phases involve a large number of participants who all have the disease of interest, whereas phase 0 or phase 1 trials are typically performed on a small number of healthy individuals.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is sponsoring a phase 3 randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a newly developed recombinant vaccine against a highly virulent novel pathogen and to generate a hypothesis about the effects of the new vaccine on herd immunity in high-risk, immunocompromised individuals. The efficacy and safety of the new vaccine have been demonstrated in a prior phase 2 trial sponsored by the same company. The researchers are conducting a trial in community hospitals in 350 towns. Each hospital is randomly assigned to administer either the standard vaccine or the new vaccine. All staff, patients, and visitors at each hospital are invited to enroll in the study. The data is collected by nurses who have full insight into the study protocol, including which group the hospital belongs to, and they transfer the data to the evaluating researchers who also have full insight into the protocol. Because they must keep records of potential side effects, the physician assistants administering the vaccines are also informed about which vaccines the participants are given. The participants are not informed about which of the two vaccines they receive. The endpoint is to compare the efficacy of the new vaccine to the standard vaccine and to form a hypothesis about its effect on herd immunity in immunocompromised individuals. Which of the following best describes the study design?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In studies with a cluster design, participants are randomized in groups or clusters rather than individually. In this study, the clusters consist of hospitals, which are randomized into either the intervention group (new vaccine) or the control group (standard vaccine), and all participants at each hospital receive the same vaccine. Cluster randomized trials have a lower risk of contamination of intervention. For example, in this study, the effects of the two vaccines can be observed separately. If the participants had been individually randomized into intervention and control groups, each vaccine's efficacy would be difficult to evaluate because of the other vaccine's effects on herd immunity in the community. Other advantages of cluster randomization include typically lower costs than other study designs and simpler enrollment procedures. On the downside, cluster randomized trials have low statistical power because the units of analysis are groups rather than individual participants. In addition, recruitment bias can occur when participants are enrolled after interventions have already been allocated to clusters.

B) INCORRECT:

In a placebo-controlled trial, the control group is given a placebo to evaluate the efficacy of the treatment used in the intervention group. In this study, the control group will receive the standard vaccine rather than a placebo. Furthermore, a placebo-controlled study design could be unethical for trials in vulnerable populations. Because this study involves a highly virulent pathogen and high-risk, immunocompromised participants, a placebo-controlled study design is inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

In a single-arm study, all participants receive the same intervention and there is no control group. In this study, participants receiving the new vaccine are being compared to participants receiving the standard vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

In a double-blinded study, both the participants and the researchers are not informed about which intervention each participant is receiving. Although the participants in this study are blinded, the researchers are not.

E) INCORRECT:

In a factorial study, multiple interventions are tested simultaneously, and their combined effects are examined. This study design can identify interactions between interventions (e.g., synergistic effects of drug combinations). The study in this scenario only compares a single dose of two vaccines.

questions.text: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a dietary supplement in decreasing the risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Eight hundred white men between 40 and 60 years of age without preexisting illnesses are randomly assigned to receive the dietary supplement or placebo. After following the subjects for 10 years, the results of the trial show no statistically significant difference in the risk of developing T2DM between the subjects receiving the supplement and the group receiving the placebo. One year later, the researchers receive another grant and decide to further analyze the data collected during the trial. They now categorize the participants into 7 groups according to the participants' fasting plasma glucose (FPG) at the beginning of the trial. One group is categorized as FPG < 70 mg/dL; the other study participants are divided into 6 groups according to the following value ranges: 70–74 mg/dL, 75–79 mg/dL, 80–84 mg/dL, 85–89 mg/dL, 90–94 mg/dL, and 95–99 mg/dL. The researchers observe that subjects with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL who took the supplement had a 4% lower risk of developing T2DM compared to subjects in this category who took the placebo. The result was statistically significant. Which of the following is the most accurate reason for questioning the internal validity of the supplement's efficacy analysis among subjects with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL?

choices.text: Results of the overall trial showed no statistically significant difference.
Participants with a higher fasting plasma glucose were more likely to withdraw from the clinical trial.
Incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus is higher in individuals with an elevated fasting plasma glucose.
Only white men without preexisting illnesses were included in the clinical trial.
Treatment response among subjects of different categories of fasting plasma glucose was not the primary outcome measure.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The statistical significance of the results of the overall trial does not affect the internal validity of the subgroup analysis. Even if the overall trial shows no statistically significant difference between the treatment groups, a properly performed subgroup analysis may be able to detect statistically significant differences for subgroups of the trial. There is a different reason to question the validity of subgroup analysis in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

Attrition bias, which can cause differences between the experimental and the control group as a result of selective loss of participants to follow-up, can limit the internal validity of a trial’s results. In this case, there is no information about selective loss to follow-up. Regardless of the possibility of an attrition bias, the subgroup analysis compares one group with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL with another group that has the same FPG. Therefore, even if participants with a higher FPG were more likely to withdraw from the clinical trial, this selective loss to follow-up would not threaten the internal validity of a subgroup analysis comparing results within one subgroup.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated plasma glucose levels (100–125 mg/dL) are defined as prediabetes and are associated with an increased risk of developing diabetes mellitus (DM). Plasma glucose levels of < 100 mg/dL are considered normal and there is no sufficient evidence that these levels are associated with an increased risk of DM. In addition, the subgroup analysis compares one group with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL with another group that has the same FPG. Therefore, even if participants with a high fasting plasma glucose were more likely to develop DM, this increased incidence would not threaten the internal validity of a subgroup analysis comparing results within one subgroup.

D) INCORRECT:

The initial results of the study lack generalizability (external validity) to the general population because of sampling bias (including only white men without preexisting illnesses). Regardless, the lack of generalizability of the initial results is no reason to question the internal validity of the subgroup analysis.

E) CORRECT:

In this scenario, subgroups (i.e., subjects of different groups, categorized according to their FPG) were determined and analyzed after the initial trial ended, raising concerns about the validity of the subgroup efficacy analysis. Posthoc subgroup analysis of the same data is associated with an increased rate of false positives or false negatives and increases the chance of coincidentally discovering statistically significant results. In addition, subgroups also have a smaller number of subjects, which leads to reduced statistical power of the subgroup analysis, making it difficult to identify true subgroup effects. The results of posthoc subgroup analysis should not be used to infer treatment effects or make clinical decisions but can be used for hypothesis generation for further clinical studies.

If subgroup analysis will be performed as a part of the study to infer treatment effects or make clinical decisions, the subgroups should be determined a priori (during the study design phase) in order to avoid selection bias and to ensure adequate sample sizes within each subgroup. In addition, only a small number of subgroups should be analyzed to avoid the multiple comparisons problem. Finally, the expected subgroup effect (direction and magnitude) should be defined before the trial and based on logical reasoning (e.g., pathophysiological considerations).

A prominent example that demonstrates the limitations of posthoc subgroup analyses is the second International Study of Infarct Survival (ISIS-2). The authors performed a posthoc subgroup analysis based on astrological birth signs on their data. According to this analysis, patients born under the astrological signs of Libra and Gemini did not benefit from one month of daily aspirin after myocardial infarction. The result of the analysis was statistically significant. The authors reported this outcome as an example of the questionable nature of posthoc subgroup analyses.

Randomized trial of intravenous streptokinase, oral aspirin, both, or neither among 17,187 cases of suspected acute myocardial infarction: ISIS-2. ISIS-2 (Second International Study of Infarct Survival) Collaborative Group. Lancet. 1988 Aug 13;2(8607):349-60. PMID: 2899772.
questions.hint: Grouping study participants into categories and analyzing these groups is a subgroup analysis. Posthoc subgroup analysis may identify a statistically significant effect, but outcomes should always be interpreted with caution.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset abdominal pain that was originally periumbilical and ultimately migrated to the right lower quadrant. He has begun vomiting and has had a fever for the past 4 hours. He is approached about participating in a research study of patients being evaluated for appendicitis, and he consents.
The goal of the study is to validate a new “serum protein Y” measurement to diagnose appendicitis. The investigators will recruit patients presenting with abdominal pain and measure their level of “serum protein Y” using point-of-care methodology. The outcome of whether appendicitis was present or not will be established by validation based on experts’ retrospective review of the clinical, laboratory, and imaging data as well as histopathologic examination of the appendix in patients who undergo appendectomy. These data will be used to establish whether the point-of-care test for “serum protein Y” may be useful in diagnosing appendicitis preoperatively.
The patient is informed that participating in the study will not provide any benefit to the patient but that the results may benefit future patients.
During the patient’s evaluation, an abdominal CT scan reveals mild thickening of the appendix with signs of surrounding inflammation. He is scheduled for urgent surgical exploration of the appendix. In the meantime, as part of the study protocol, a research assistant obtains a drop of blood with a fingerstick and brings the sample back to the research laboratory (next to the emergency department) where the “serum protein Y” test is done using point-of-care technology. The result returns very low, which the investigators have hypothesized may indicate low risk for appendicitis. The research assistant enters the result into the study database for future analysis. The patient continues to await his surgery.
At the current time, who should the research assistant inform about the results of the experimental test?

choices.text: The principal investigator of the study
The principal investigator of the study, the surgeon, and the patient

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When clinical studies are taking place, the principal investigator (PI) should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias). Study findings are shared before the end of the study only when the results are so significant that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others.

B) CORRECT:

The ideal assessment of a new diagnostic test requires comparison to the currently best diagnostic test (i.e., the gold-standard test). Given that the serum marker being investigated in this case is currently experimental and that the current gold standard of evaluation (abdominal CT) suggests that this patient has appendicitis, the patient’s care should proceed as planned regardless of the results of the experimental test.

When clinical studies are taking place, both the principal investigator (PI) and the treating clinicians should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias). Study findings are shared with the PI and clinicians only when the results are so significant before the end of the study that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others.

Once the predictive value of the experimental test becomes known, its use may begin to inform clinical decisions.

Key learning point: The most important facet of determining accuracy of a new diagnostic test is comparison with the gold standard.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient’s care should proceed as planned regardless of the results of the experimental test. When clinical studies are taking place, the treating clinicians should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias). Study findings are shared before the end of the study only when the results are so significant that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient’s care should proceed as planned regardless of the results of the experimental test. When clinical studies are taking place, the treating clinicians should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias). Study findings are shared before the end of the study only when the results are so significant that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient’s care should proceed as planned regardless of the results of the experimental test. When clinical studies are taking place, both the principal investigator (PI) and the treating clinicians should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias). Study findings are shared before the end of the study only when the results are so significant that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with obesity presents for follow-up of type 2 diabetes that was diagnosed on screening blood tests one year ago. Since this diagnosis, the patient has instituted lifestyle changes and has been taking metformin 500 mg twice daily; he developed nausea on higher doses. His most recent glycated hemoglobin level is 6.7% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
During the visit, he asks about the prognosis of his diabetes. He is specifically concerned about whether his condition might worsen over time and require more-intense interventions, such as insulin therapy.
In a search for information to answer the patient’s question, which one of the following study designs would be most likely to yield useful data on the long-term prognosis of a common condition such as type 2 diabetes?

choices.text: Long-term follow-up of participants in a randomized controlled trial

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies can offer valuable information about patients’ long-term outcomes, especially when the condition of interest is rare and may not be detected in a large cohort. However, the retrospective collection of data can bias the findings.

B) INCORRECT:

A long-term follow-up study of patients in a randomized controlled trial is similar in design to the prospective cohort study, but the outcome data may be unduly influenced by the intervention studied. In addition, the population of patients who meet the many criteria for enrollment in a clinical trial that focuses on a specific condition may not represent the broad population of patients with that condition.

C) INCORRECT:

A case series can provide data on patient outcomes, but it is hard to draw conclusions from this type of study because it often involves a small sample of patients selected in nonrandomized fashion (for example, a group of patients followed at a particular institution for a particular reason).

D) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies evaluate disease characteristics at a specific point in time. This type of observational study does not adequately elucidate the prognosis of a condition.

E) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies represent the type of study best suited to elucidate the prognosis of a common disease process. At baseline, none of the subjects has developed the outcome of interest, but the assumption is that a sufficient number will develop it during the study to allow for useful statistical analysis. The data are collected prospectively to avoid recall bias. Disease conditions that have a low incidence are difficult to study with this design, because not many of the participants would develop the disease during the study.

Key learning point: The type of study that is most likely to yield valuable information about the long-term prognosis of a commonly diagnosed condition is a prospective cohort study.

questions.text:
During rounds with your medical students, you examine a 33-year-old man in the intensive care unit who suffered second-degree burns over 24% of his body-surface area. One of the students asks whether checking the patient’s procalcitonin levels would be useful to detect early signs of sepsis.
Which one of the following study designs would be most useful in determining the predictive value of procalcitonin levels for detecting sepsis in a burn patient such as this one?

choices.text: Case series of 25 burn patients who developed sepsis, with graphs of daily procalcitonin levels for each patient
Prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
An animal study in which procalcitonin levels are measured in mice with and without sepsis
Meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
Case-control study evaluating procalcitonin levels in hospitalized burn patients who developed sepsis (cases) and those who did not (controls)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A case series is a descriptive study about a group of patients with the same disease or condition who all have the exposure of interest (in this case, measurement of procalcitonin levels). Although this type of study can be used to generate hypotheses, it does not include a comparison group, which makes drawing conclusions about causality very difficult.

B) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients whose procalcitonin levels were tracked over time would yield more information than a case-control study, because it could quantify the incidence of sepsis among burn patients and better describe how trends in procalcitonin did or did not predict the development of sepsis. A single study of this type is limited by its sample size, the number of institutions involved, and other factors that may make the study population different from the population of all hospitalized burn patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Animal studies are far less likely than observational human studies to provide clinically useful data.

D) CORRECT:

All clinical research studies are subject to both random and systematic error that can lead to incorrect conclusions about the answer to a research question. Random error stems primarily from chance and inadequate sample size, whereas systematic error stems from study-design flaws that lead to an incorrect result regardless of sample size.

The hierarchy of evidence stipulates that different study designs have different inferential power and different likelihoods of systematic error. Studies that are higher in the hierarchy are more likely to represent the true answer to a clinical question than those that are lower. Randomized controlled trials are at the top of the hierarchy for most clinical questions but are not always feasible. For observational studies, the hierarchy of evidence is as follows, in order of ascending validity: case series, cross-sectional study, case-control study, retrospective cohort study, prospective cohort study, and systemic review or meta-analysis of cohort studies.

A meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies has the advantage of effectively increasing the sample size (by including information from multiple studies or sources) and using statistical methods to pool the results. Although each study included in the meta-analysis may be subject to bias in one direction or another, the combination of study results is more likely to lead to an accurate approximation of a statistical association than any one study alone.

Key learning point: The hierarchy of evidence for observational studies, in order of ascending validity, is case series, case-control study, cohort study, and systematic review or meta-analysis of cohort studies.

E) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies compare the characteristics of individuals who already have a particular disease (cases) with the characteristics of individuals who do not have that disease (controls). These studies are very useful for rare diseases, but the investigators do not follow patients over time and thus cannot calculate incidence. Although a case-control study comparing the procalcitonin levels among burn patients who developed sepsis with those who did not would be a valid design, it would be less informative and more prone to bias than study types that are higher on the hierarchy of evidence.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents for routine care and notes that her father was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. She is concerned about her own risk of diabetes and asks whether eating more fruit and vegetables might help reduce this risk. She recalls reading a newspaper article about a study that investigated this question.
The study was designed to examine the link between fruit and vegetable intake and the development of type 2 diabetes. The investigators interviewed patients from multiple primary care practices who had recently been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and asked them to estimate the average number of servings of fruits and vegetables they ate per day in the year preceding the diagnosis. Similar interviews were conducted in age- and sex-matched controls who did not have diabetes.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding the design of this study?

choices.text: The study is prone to selection bias, which could have been prevented by enrolling study participants from specialized tertiary care referral centers only
Asking participants with type 2 diabetes about their prior intake of fruits and vegetables may have introduced recall bias
The selection of participants who are already diagnosed with the outcome at the time of investigation helps increase the validity of the study
The study design makes attrition of participants a major source of bias
By matching for age and sex, the investigators have introduced overmatching bias

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Selection bias occurs when the study population is not representative of the larger population of interest in a way that affects interpretation of the exposure-outcome relationship. For example, limiting participants to a specialty clinic in a tertiary care center is less likely to represent the population at large than drawing from multiple primary care practices and is therefore more likely to introduce selection bias.

B) CORRECT:

In case-control studies, such as the one described here, researchers identify individuals with and without the outcome of interest (in this case, type 2 diabetes) and then obtain a history of their potential exposures (in this case, fruit and vegetable intake). The researchers then study the exposure-outcome relationship by comparing the degree of exposure in those with and without the outcome.

Case-control studies are limited by how accurately the exposure of interest is assessed. If it is assessed using participant recollection, there is potential for inaccuracy in the reporting and systematic errors can be introduced. This is known as recall bias and may be affected by factors such as age, education, and the nature of the outcome being studied. Behaviors that are generally perceived as unfavorable, such as alcohol use, smoking, and poor diet, may be particularly susceptible to recall bias.

Key learning point: Retrospective studies where cases and controls are interviewed about past exposures as possible risk factors for a disease may be susceptible to recall bias.

C) INCORRECT:

In general, retrospective studies are low on the hierarchy of evidence because of their susceptibility to bias. Randomized controlled trials are the preferred design for obtaining high-quality evidence for an exposure-outcome relationship.

D) INCORRECT:

Attrition bias is a form of selection bias that occurs because of participant dropout and is more prevalent in prospective studies than in retrospective studies like the one described here.

E) INCORRECT:

Overmatching bias can occur if the cases and controls are matched on an unnecessarily high number of characteristics, which can reduce the power and efficiency of analyses. However, matching on age and sex alone is not likely to introduce this form of bias.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman with stage IV ovarian cancer presents for follow-up after cytoreductive surgery and completion of first-line chemotherapy with bevacizumab, carboplatin, and paclitaxel.
She currently has no evidence of disease and a normal cancer-antigen-125 level. The plan is to continue maintenance chemotherapy, and her oncologist reported that a new trial supported adding olaparib to the current standard of care, which is bevacizumab. The patient asks your opinion on the data.
In reviewing the literature, you find a randomized controlled trial comparing the addition of olaparib or placebo to maintenance chemotherapy with bevacizumab in ovarian cancer. The trial’s efficacy data were analyzed in the intention-to-treat population.
What is the immediate effect of using the intention-to-treat population to analyze the efficacy data in this study?

choices.text: It makes the results more generalizable to a larger population
It avoids loss of data when patients are lost to follow-up
It ensures that only the participants receiving their allocated treatment are included in the analysis
It provides the most accurate reflection of the true biologic effect of the treatment
It maintains the balance generated in the original randomization process for each treatment group

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat analysis preserves the benefits of the randomization and better reflects real-world settings (where patients do not always follow the treatment plans laid out for them), but it may also underestimate the true efficacy of an intervention. Of note, intention-to-treat analysis is simply an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not improve the generalizability of the trial results.

B) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat analysis is simply an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not mitigate data loss due to loss of follow-up.

C) INCORRECT:

In intention-to-treat analysis, all study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to, regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study.

D) INCORRECT:

Per-protocol analysis may provide a better estimate of the true biologic effect of an intervention if it is fully followed, but the results may be subject to bias if there was differential loss to follow-up or differential adherence between the two groups.

E) CORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are designed to reduce as many differences as possible between the two groups being studied, so that any difference observed between the groups can truly be attributed to the intervention being studied. Randomization (the act of randomly assigning study participants to receive either the intervention or the comparison protocol) is important because it ensures that the groups have a similar distribution of measured and unmeasured baseline characteristics. However, participants do not always fully follow the protocol they were assigned to; for example, they might discontinue the intervention because of adverse events, cross over to the alternative intervention, or not return for follow-up.

Researchers have two options for how they analyze data from these individuals:

• Intention-to-treat analysis: All study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to, regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study.
• Per-protocol analysis: Study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis.

Intention-to-treat analysis preserves the benefits of the randomization and better reflects real-world settings (where patients do not always follow the treatment plans laid out for them), but it may also underestimate the true efficacy of an intervention. Per-protocol analysis may provide a better estimate of the true biologic effect of an intervention if it is fully followed, but the results may be subject to bias if there was differential loss to follow-up or differential adherence between the two groups.

Of note, intention-to-treat analysis is simply an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not mitigate data loss due to loss of follow-up or improve the generalizability of the trial results.

Key learning point: The purpose of using an intention-to-treat analysis in a randomized controlled trial is to minimize bias by maintaining the randomization process.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and obesity (BMI, 45) presents for routine care. Despite nonpharmacologic and medical therapy, her weight and BMI have increased during the past 3 years. You are considering referring her for bariatric surgery to manage her weight. Before doing so, you review the literature and find several studies with conflicting conclusions.
Which one of the following studies identified during your literature search would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in managing this patient’s weight?

choices.text: A retrospective observational study describing the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss
A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
A systematic review of randomized controlled trials and observational studies describing the effect of gastric bypass surgery on weight loss
A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on insulin sensitivity
The randomized controlled trial with the largest number of participants comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An observational study does not benefit from the randomization process inherent in randomized controlled trials. Furthermore, a different type of study that involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study.

B) CORRECT:

Meta-analysis is a method of analyzing data from multiple studies to create a numerical summary and estimate of effect. A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis of a meta-analysis if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. Meta-analysis is particularly useful when different studies yield different estimates of the overall effect of interest.

Because meta-analysis involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies, it provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study (even a very large randomized controlled trial). The sample size is larger in a meta-analysis than in a single study, which is useful for trials that are underpowered. Furthermore, meta-analysis of data from randomized controlled trials retains the benefits of randomization. The numerical summary generated by a meta-analysis, usually expressed as a risk ratio or odds ratio, provides an additional layer of information that a systematic review lacks.

Meta-analysis is only as good as the data being analyzed, which is one of its main limitations. If a meta-analysis includes studies that were designed with a high risk of bias or studies that have slightly different end points, the results will be less reliable or informative than if the analysis included only higher-quality studies or studies with the same end points. Meta-analyses can also amplify publication bias because they only include published studies, and negative studies are less likely to be submitted or published.

Key learning point: The advantages of meta-analysis are that it incorporates multiple analyses, combines information from randomized trials, and provides a numeric summary.

C) INCORRECT:

A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis of a meta-analysis if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. However, a comparison of the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

In this case scenario, the stated outcome of interest is weight loss; therefore, a meta-analysis with weight loss as the outcome of interest will be more relevant than one that looks at insulin sensitivity as the outcome of interest.

E) INCORRECT:

Because meta-analysis involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies, it provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study (even a very large randomized controlled trial). Moreover, the sample size is larger in a meta-analysis than in a single study.

A 38-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, and a BMI of 46 is interested in bariatric surgery to help with weight loss and the management of his comorbid conditions. He began gaining significant weight as a young teenager and has since cycled between dieting, weight loss, and rebound weight gain. He asks whether you think bariatric surgery would provide a longer lasting weight-loss solution.
Looking for answers to his question, you find the Longitudinal Assessment of Bariatric Surgery (LABS) study, a prospective, observational, multicenter cohort study designed to evaluate the long-term effects of bariatric surgery on the health and wellness of patients with severe obesity. LABS researchers enrolled adults with obesity who were about to undergo first-time bariatric surgery (either Roux-en-Y gastric bypass [RYGB\] or gastric banding) and followed them over time with serial measurements of outcomes related to weight loss and remission of comorbid conditions, such as diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.
The 7-year outcomes of the study showed that participants had sustained weight loss — as well as a reduced prevalence of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia — compared with baseline. In a subgroup analysis, those who had undergone gastric banding had significantly lower rates of diabetes remission than those who had undergone RYGB.
What is a common limitation with this type of study design?

choices.text: An inappropriate control group introducing bias
Outcome data that rely on measurements obtained during routine medical care
A subset of eligible patients declining enrollment to avoid being randomized to a treatment arm they prefer to avoid
A high likelihood of participant attrition or loss to follow-up over the study period
Participants differing in their ability to recall the exposure, leading to recall bias

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies are observational studies that follow a predetermined group over time. Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. Individuals with a specific disease or outcome (cases) are compared to those without the disease or outcome (controls). This design may be limited by an inappropriate choice of the control group.

B) INCORRECT:

Study procedures are often as rigorous in prospective cohort studies as they are in interventional studies, with study visits to obtain a uniform data set (rather than reliance on data obtained in routine clinical care only).

C) INCORRECT:

Unlike in interventional studies, such as randomized controlled trials, cohort studies do not alter the participants’ exposure. The exposure is determined by other factors, and the investigator is simply following participants over time to assess the effect of the exposure on the outcome of interest.

D) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies are observational studies that follow a predetermined group over time. They are useful in demonstrating the effect of interventions or exposures on outcomes, determining a sequence of events, and studying the effect of time on the group.

Study procedures are often as rigorous in prospective cohort studies as they are in interventional studies, with study visits to obtain a uniform data set (rather than reliance on data obtained in routine clinical care only). Because information about the exposure of interest is obtained close to the time of the actual exposure, the risk of recall bias is reduced. However, prospective cohort studies typically take place over long periods of time, which can be costly in terms of time and funding and can also lead to participant attrition or loss to follow-up.

Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. Individuals with a specific disease or outcome (cases) are compared to those without the disease or outcome (controls). This design may be prone to recall bias if participants are asked to retrospectively recall their exposure and may also be limited by an inappropriate choice of the control group. Recall bias may also affect other study designs such as retrospective cohort studies and cross-sectional studies.

Unlike in interventional studies, such as randomized controlled trials, cohort studies do not alter the participants’ exposure. The exposure is determined by other factors, and the investigator is simply following participants over time to assess the effect of the exposure on the outcome of interest.

Key learning point: One limitation of prospective cohort studies is the duration of involvement by study participants, which adds to the expense of the study and can lead to loss of follow-up data from participants.

questions.text:
A 13-month-old girl presents with fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and foul-smelling urine. A urinalysis is positive for white cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites. You prescribe 10 days of oral cefixime and discuss close follow-up with the family.
One week later, the patient is afebrile, eating well, and in no distress. A voiding cystourethrogram reveals grade 2 vesicoureteral reflux. The family asks how to proceed.
In reviewing the literature, you find a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux.
Which one of the following statements about this study’s design is true?

choices.text: This study is designed to optimize the ability to make inferences about the effect of prophylactic antibiotics on the outcome.
The study design allows the most accurate measurement of the outcome of urinary tract infections and renal scarring.
The study design ensures that even adverse effects of prophylactic antibiotics can be identified.
The statistical analyses performed in this type of study are different from those performed in other study types.
This study is designed to optimize generalizability of the results to all children with vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The primary advantage of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is high internal validity so that a causal inference can be made about the intervention (in this case, prophylactic antibiotics) and the outcome (urinary tract infections and renal scarring). Random allocation to the treatment groups (which leads to balancing of potential confounders between the groups) and blinding allow the investigators to attribute any observed differences in the primary outcome between treatment groups to the intervention and not to other causes. Thus, the advantage of the study identified is that it allows the researchers to determine whether antibiotics are beneficial in preventing urinary tract infections and scarring.

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

Key learning point: The main advantage of a randomized controlled trial design, despite its compromise of external generalizability, is high internal validity to permit inference about causation.

B) INCORRECT:

The accuracy of the outcome metric is not affected by the study design. It is determined by the manner in which the researchers are able to measure or determine the outcome. An accurate measure of the outcome is important for a clinical trial, but it is equally important for any other research study design.

C) INCORRECT:

RCTs are not feasible for rare disorders, because it is difficult to recruit enough patients that meet the enrollment criteria. Similarly, although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

D) INCORRECT:

The statistical analyses used for clinical trials are similar to those used in other study designs. Randomization in a clinical trial allows estimation of the causal effect, but the statistical approaches used are not different in this study design than in others.

Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants. Similarly, although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

questions.text:
Researchers have postulated that intrauterine insults, possibly related to certain drugs taken during pregnancy, might cause a rare type of cancer that typically develops in the second decade of life.
Which one of the following types of studies is most appropriate and cost-effective for determining whether the postulated association is real?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a prospective cohort study, researchers define a cohort of patients and then follow them to see who develops the outcome of interest. This study design would not be suitable to answer the question at hand in a timely, cost-effective fashion.

B) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are not ideal for studying exposures for which the outcome of interest takes a long time to develop.

C) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional surveys are best for establishing the prevalence of a disorder at a particular moment in time.

D) CORRECT:

Case-control studies are useful for evaluating relationships between rare outcomes and multiple past exposures during a long period of time. Given the retrospective study design and lack of intervention, case-control studies are relatively inexpensive to conduct compared with randomized controlled trials (RCTs). The major challenges with conducting case-control studies are matching appropriate controls to the cases and preventing or minimizing recall bias.

Key learning point: The most appropriate and cost-effective study design for determining whether intrauterine exposures are associated with a rare type of cancer later in life is a case-control design.

E) INCORRECT:

In a crossover study, patients serve as their own controls to limit confounding. This type of study is typically used to study the treatment effects of drugs.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute-onset abdominal pain that was originally periumbilical and ultimately migrated to the right lower quadrant. He has begun vomiting and has had a fever for the past 4 hours. He is approached about participating in a research study of patients being evaluated for appendicitis, and he and his father consent.
The goal of the study is to validate a new “serum protein Y” measurement to diagnose appendicitis. The investigators will recruit patients presenting with abdominal pain and measure their level of “serum protein Y” using point-of-care methodology. The outcome of whether appendicitis was present or not will be established by validation based on experts’ retrospective review of the clinical, laboratory, and imaging data as well as histopathologic examination of the appendix in patients who undergo appendectomy. These data will be used to establish whether the point-of-care test for “serum protein Y” may be useful in diagnosing appendicitis preoperatively.
The patient and his father are informed that participating in the study will not provide any benefit to the patient but that the results may benefit future patients.
During the patient’s evaluation, an abdominal CT scan reveals mild thickening of the appendix with signs of surrounding inflammation. He is scheduled for urgent surgical exploration of the appendix. As part of the study protocol, a research assistant obtains a drop of blood with a fingerstick and brings the sample back to the research laboratory (next to the emergency department) where the “serum protein Y” test is done using point-of-care technology. The result returns very low, which the investigators have hypothesized may indicate low risk for appendicitis. The research assistant enters the result into the study database for future analysis.
