questions.text:
A 10-month-old boy with a diagnosis of infantile gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) continues to have symptoms attributed to his GERD (frequent regurgitation, poor feeding, and irritability). His parents ask about the prognosis of infantile GERD.
In a search for information to answer the parents' question, which one of the following study designs would be most likely to yield useful data on the long-term prognosis of a common condition such as GERD?

choices.text: Long-term follow-up of participants in a randomized controlled trial

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies evaluate disease characteristics at a specific point in time. This type of observational study does not adequately elucidate the prognosis of a condition.

B) INCORRECT:

A long-term follow-up study of patients in a randomized controlled trial is similar in design to the prospective cohort study, but the outcome data may be unduly influenced by the intervention studied. In addition, the population of patients who meet the many criteria for enrollment in a clinical trial that focuses on a specific condition may not represent the broad population of patients with that condition.

C) INCORRECT:

A case series can provide data on patient outcomes, but it is hard to draw conclusions from this type of study because it often involves a small sample of patients selected in nonrandomized fashion (for example, a group of patients followed at a particular institution for a particular reason).

D) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies represent the type of study best suited to elucidate the prognosis of a common disease process. At baseline, none of the subjects has developed the outcome of interest, but the assumption is that a sufficient number will develop it during the study to allow for useful statistical analysis. The data are collected prospectively to avoid recall bias. Disease conditions that have a low incidence are difficult to study with this design, because not many of the participants would develop the disease during the study.

Key learning point: The type of study that is most likely to yield valuable information about the long-term prognosis of a commonly diagnosed condition is a prospective cohort study.

E) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies can offer valuable information about patients’ long-term outcomes, especially when the condition of interest is rare and may not be detected in a large cohort. However, the retrospective collection of data can bias the findings.

questions.text:
During rounds with your medical students, you examine a 3-year-old boy in the intensive care unit who suffered second-degree burns over about 40% of his body-surface area. One of the students asks whether checking the patient’s procalcitonin levels would be useful to detect early signs of sepsis.
Which one of the following study designs would be most useful in determining the predictive value of procalcitonin levels for detecting sepsis in a burn patient such as this one?

choices.text: Case-control study evaluating procalcitonin levels in hospitalized burn patients who developed sepsis (cases) and those who did not (controls)
Prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
An animal study in which procalcitonin levels are measured in mice with and without sepsis
Case series of 25 burn patients who developed sepsis, with graphs of daily procalcitonin levels for each patient
Meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies compare the characteristics of individuals who already have a particular disease (cases) with the characteristics of individuals who do not have that disease (controls). These studies are very useful for rare diseases, but the investigators do not follow patients over time and thus cannot calculate incidence. Although a case-control study comparing the procalcitonin levels among burn patients who developed sepsis with those who did not would be a valid design, it would be less informative and more prone to bias than study types that are higher on the hierarchy of evidence.

B) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients whose procalcitonin levels were tracked over time would yield more information, because it could quantify the incidence of sepsis among burn patients and better describe how trends in procalcitonin did or did not predict the development of sepsis. A single study of this type is limited by its sample size, the number of institutions involved, and other factors that may make the study population different from the population of all hospitalized burn patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Animal studies are far less likely than observational human studies to provide clinically useful data.

D) INCORRECT:

A case series is a descriptive study about a group of patients with the same disease or condition who all have the exposure of interest (in this case, measurement of procalcitonin levels). Although this type of study can be used to generate hypotheses, it does not include a comparison group, which makes drawing conclusions about causality very difficult.

E) CORRECT:

All clinical research studies are subject to both random and systematic error that can lead to incorrect conclusions about the answer to a research question. Random error stems primarily from chance and inadequate sample size, whereas systematic error stems from study-design flaws that lead to an incorrect result regardless of sample size.

The hierarchy of evidence stipulates that different study designs have different inferential power and different likelihoods of systematic error. Studies that are higher in the hierarchy are more likely to represent the true answer to a clinical question than those that are lower. Randomized controlled trials are at the top of the hierarchy for most clinical questions but are not always feasible. For observational studies, the hierarchy of evidence is as follows, in order of ascending validity: case series, cross-sectional study, case-control study, retrospective cohort study, prospective cohort study, and systemic review or meta-analysis of cohort studies.

Key learning point: The hierarchy of evidence for observational studies, in order of ascending validity, is case series, case-control study, cohort study, and systematic review or meta-analysis of cohort studies.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents for a routine annual visit with her father, who tells you that he was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He is concerned about his daughter’s risk of developing diabetes and asks whether eating more fruit and vegetables might help reduce this risk. He recalls reading a newspaper article about a study that investigated this question.
The study was designed to examine the link between fruit and vegetable intake and the development of type 2 diabetes. The investigators interviewed patients from multiple primary care practices who had recently been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and asked them to estimate the average number of servings of fruits and vegetables they ate per day in the year preceding the diagnosis. Similar interviews were conducted in age- and sex-matched controls who did not have diabetes.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding the design of this study?

choices.text: By matching for age and sex, the investigators have introduced overmatching bias
The study is prone to selection bias, which could have been prevented by enrolling study participants from specialized tertiary care referral centers only
The selection of participants who are already diagnosed with the outcome at the time of investigation helps increase the validity of the study
The study design makes attrition of participants a major source of bias
Asking participants with type 2 diabetes about their prior intake of fruits and vegetables may have introduced recall bias

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overmatching bias can occur if the cases and controls are matched on an unnecessarily high number of characteristics, which can reduce the power and efficiency of analyses. However, matching on age and sex alone is not likely to introduce this form of bias.

B) INCORRECT:

Selection bias occurs when the study population is not representative of the larger population of interest in a way that affects interpretation of the exposure-outcome relationship. For example, limiting participants to a specialty clinic in a tertiary care center is less likely to represent the population at large than drawing from multiple primary care practices and is therefore more likely to introduce selection bias.

C) INCORRECT:

In general, retrospective studies are low on the hierarchy of evidence because of their susceptibility to bias. Randomized controlled trials are the preferred design for obtaining high-quality evidence for an exposure-outcome relationship.

D) INCORRECT:

Attrition bias is a form of selection bias that occurs because of participant dropout and is more prevalent in prospective studies than in retrospective studies like the one described here.

E) CORRECT:

In case-control studies, such as the one described here, researchers identify individuals with and without the outcome of interest (in this case, type 2 diabetes) and then obtain a history of their potential exposures (in this case, fruit and vegetable intake). The researchers then study the exposure-outcome relationship by comparing the degree of exposure in those with and without the outcome.

Case-control studies are limited by how accurately the exposure of interest is assessed. If it is assessed using participant recollection, there is potential for inaccuracy in the reporting and systematic errors can be introduced. This is known as recall bias and may be affected by factors such as age, education, and the nature of the outcome being studied. Behaviors that are generally perceived as unfavorable, such as alcohol use, smoking, and poor diet, may be particularly susceptible to recall bias.

Key learning point: Retrospective studies where cases and controls are interviewed about past exposures as possible risk factors for a disease may be susceptible to recall bias.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents for a routine visit. Her mother mentions that her previously healthy father — the child’s grandfather — was recently diagnosed with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The mother reports that she has been preoccupied with the diagnosis and has subsequently tried to limit her family’s exposure to potential carcinogens.
She has read multiple media reports about exposures to plastics and the development of pancreatic cancer. She asks you about the carcinogenic potential of bisphenol A (BPA) in the plastic containers that she uses to pack and microwave lunches for her daughter. You decide to review the literature in an attempt to answer her question.
Which one of the following types of research studies would be most appropriate to answer this patient’s question?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies are a type of observational study in which population-level data are analyzed at a single point in time. Because of the descriptive nature of these studies, they cannot be used to estimate the risk difference or determine the temporal relationship between the exposure and the outcome.

B) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are superior in the hierarchy of evidence because of their ability to limit bias. Although this type of study can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical. This same limitation applies to crossover trials, in which patients are randomized to a series of exposures.

C) INCORRECT:

A case series is a type of descriptive study that is used to report rare or novel associations between an exposure and an outcome. This type of study is useful for documenting rare clinical events but cannot provide analytical measures such as risk difference.

D) INCORRECT:

Although crossover trials, in which patients are randomized to a series of exposures, can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical. This same limitation applies to randomized controlled trials.

E) CORRECT:

The study design that is best suited to investigate the link between environmental exposures and rare outcomes is a cohort study. In prospective cohort studies, groups of patients who do and do not have the exposure in question are followed to determine if they develop a defined outcome. This type of study provides a direct measure of risk difference (incidence in the exposed group minus incidence in the unexposed group). In this example, the exposed cohort would be those who had exposure to bisphenol A (BPA), and the outcome would be the development of pancreatic cancer.

An alternative way to address this question would be a case-control study. In this type of study, researchers enroll individuals who already have or do not have the outcome in question (in this case, pancreatic cancer). These individuals are then studied retrospectively to determine their exposures. This study design is subject to recall bias, which can limit the strength of the conclusions drawn.

Key learning point: The two study designs best suited to assess whether an environmental exposure may be causing a rare outcome are cohort studies and case-control studies.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents for follow-up of type 1 diabetes. He was diagnosed 5 years ago and has been on a standard regimen of multiple daily injections of insulin. His most recent glycated hemoglobin level was 7.6%. His parents are considering initiation of an insulin pump with a continuous glucose monitor, an option that is covered by their insurance, but they are also considering whether to pursue having a closed-loop system of insulin delivery approved for coverage. They ask for your opinion on the two options.
In reviewing the literature, you find a randomized controlled trial comparing a closed-loop system of insulin delivery with a sensor-augmented insulin pump. The trial’s efficacy data were analyzed in the intention-to-treat population.
What is the main advantage of using the intention-to-treat population to analyze the efficacy data in this study?

choices.text: It ensures that only the participants receiving their allocated treatment are included in the analysis
It provides the most accurate reflection of the true biologic effect of the treatment
It maintains the balance generated in the original randomization process for each treatment group
It avoids loss of data when patients are lost to follow-up
It makes the results more generalizable to a larger population

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In intention-to-treat analysis, all study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to, regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study. In per-protocol analysis, study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat analysis may underestimate the true efficacy of an intervention. Per-protocol analysis may provide a better estimate of the true biologic effect of an intervention.

C) CORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are designed to reduce as many differences as possible between the two groups being studied, so that any difference observed between the groups can truly be attributed to the intervention being studied. Randomization (the act of randomly assigning study participants to receive either the intervention or the comparison protocol) is important because it ensures that the groups have a similar distribution of measured and unmeasured baseline characteristics. However, participants do not always fully follow the protocol they were assigned to; for example, they might discontinue the intervention because of adverse events, cross over to the alternative intervention, or not return for follow-up.

Researchers have two options for how they analyze data from these individuals:

• Intention-to-treat analysis: All study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to, regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study.
• Per-protocol analysis: Study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis.

Intention-to-treat analysis preserves the benefits of the randomization and better reflects real-world settings (where patients do not always follow the treatment plans laid out for them), but it may also underestimate the true efficacy of an intervention. Per-protocol analysis may provide a better estimate of the true biologic effect of an intervention if it is fully followed, but the results may be subject to bias if there was differential loss to follow-up or differential adherence between the two groups.

Of note, intention-to-treat analysis is simply an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not mitigate data loss due to loss of follow-up or improve the generalizability of the trial results.

Key learning point: The purpose of using an intention-to-treat analysis in a randomized controlled trial is to minimize bias by maintaining the randomization process.

D) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat analysis is simply an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not mitigate data loss due to loss of follow-up.

E) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat analysis is simply an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not improve the generalizability of the trial results.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old boy presents for a routine well-child visit. His mother brings him to the appointment and reports that she lives with her partner, who is a smoker. She asks you about the health effects of household smoking on children, especially on the risk of developing childhood asthma.
In your literature search, you find an observational study describing the effect of cigarette smoking on childhood health outcomes in 5000 children. An unadjusted analysis of the data from 10-year follow-up shows that childhood exposure to household tobacco smoke is associated with a high risk of developing childhood asthma.
Which one of the following strategies would have been appropriate for the researchers to use to address confounding in this study?

choices.text: Increase the follow-up time of the study
Increase the sample size of the study
Adjust the analysis for sex, socioeconomic class, and exposure to air pollution
Change the study design to a randomized controlled trial

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although increasing the sample size and follow-up time of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how many participants were included or how long they were followed.

B) INCORRECT:

Although increasing the sample size and follow-up time of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how many participants were included or how long they were followed.

C) CORRECT:

Confounders are factors that affect both the exposure and the outcome in a study. For example, in this study, a possible confounder is air pollution, which could be associated with both household tobacco smoke (the exposure of interest) and the development of childhood asthma (the outcome of interest). If this confounder is not properly accounted for, then the observed association between household tobacco smoke and childhood asthma could be incorrectly interpreted to signify causation. Researchers can address and reduce confounding during study design, analysis, or both.

Because confounders are prevalent in observational studies, they should also be adjusted for in the analysis. Multivariable regression models and propensity score methods can be used to do this. Multivariable regression models include the confounders in the model for the outcome and allow estimation of the association between the exposure and the outcome, controlling for the confounders. Propensity score methods estimate the probability of exposure and then estimate the group difference using the propensity score. Approaches to using the propensity score include matching on the propensity score, controlling for or stratifying on the propensity score, and inverse probability weighting using a function of the propensity score.

Key learning point: Confounders are factors that can introduce bias in a study by affecting both the exposure and the outcome.

D) INCORRECT:

Adjustment for multiplicity is an approach to handle performing many statistical tests in a single analysis, but it does not address confounding.

E) INCORRECT:

One way to address confounders during study design is by choosing to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, there are scenarios where RCTs are impractical or unethical, such as evaluating the long-term effects of household tobacco smoke exposure in children. In observational studies, the effects of confounding can be minimized during study design by restricting the inclusion criteria so that the study population is homogenous with respect to a particular variable — for example, by including only a certain socioeconomic class.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents after receiving a new diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Genetic analysis showed that the cancer is Philadelphia chromosome positive (Ph+), and you are now deciding which chemotherapy regimen to initiate. You review the recently published results of a randomized controlled trial that compared a new chemotherapy agent with standard care in children with Ph+ ALL. The primary outcome was progression-free survival.
What is the main question that this study was designed to address?

choices.text: Is the new chemotherapy agent better than standard care at improving progression-free survival in patients with ALL?
Do patients with Ph+ ALL live longer if they are treated with the new chemotherapy agent?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent, compared with standard care, on progression-free survival in children with Ph+ ALL?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent on progression-free survival in children with ALL?
What is the best chemotherapy agent for patients with Ph+ ALL?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one). This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

B) INCORRECT:

RCTs cannot directly account for multifactorial effects that are difficult to measure and thus cannot determine which treatment is best on balance.

C) CORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are used to evaluate whether a particular intervention has caused a particular outcome. The design of RCTs ensures that intervention groups are treated the same except for the intervention that is being studied, and the process of randomization and blinding (if present) minimizes confounding and bias so that the effect of the treatment can be estimated. RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one).

RCTs attempt to isolate the intervention so that any effects on the outcome are solely attributed to the intervention instead of other factors. This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

Secondary analyses can be performed in RCTs to explore effects other than the prespecified primary outcome, but conclusions drawn from these analyses may be less certain.

Key learning point: Randomized controlled trials are best designed to answer the question of whether a treatment has caused a specific measured effect in a select population.

D) INCORRECT:

RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one). This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

E) INCORRECT:

RCTs cannot directly account for multifactorial effects that are difficult to measure and thus cannot determine which treatment is best on balance.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with type 2 diabetes and obesity (BMI, 41) presents for routine care. Despite nonpharmacologic and medical therapy, her weight and BMI have increased during the past 3 years. You are considering referring her for bariatric surgery to manage her weight. Before doing so, you review the literature and find several studies with conflicting conclusions.
Which one of the following studies identified during your literature search would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in managing this patient’s weight?

choices.text: A systematic review of randomized controlled trials and observational studies describing the effect of gastric bypass surgery on weight loss
The randomized controlled trial with the largest number of participants comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
A retrospective observational study describing the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss
A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on insulin sensitivity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis of a meta-analysis if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. However, a comparison of the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Because meta-analysis involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies, it provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study (even a very large randomized controlled trial). Moreover, the sample size is larger in a meta-analysis than in a single study.

C) INCORRECT:

An observational study does not benefit from the randomization process inherent in randomized controlled trials. Furthermore, a different type of study that involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study.

D) CORRECT:

Meta-analysis is a method of analyzing data from multiple studies to create a numerical summary and estimate of effect. A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis of a meta-analysis if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. Meta-analysis is particularly useful when different studies yield different estimates of the overall effect of interest.

Because meta-analysis involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies, it provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study (even a very large randomized controlled trial). The sample size is larger in a meta-analysis than in a single study, which is useful for trials that are underpowered. Furthermore, meta-analysis of data from randomized controlled trials retains the benefits of randomization. The numerical summary generated by a meta-analysis, usually expressed as a risk ratio or odds ratio, provides an additional layer of information that a systematic review lacks.

Meta-analysis is only as good as the data being analyzed, which is one of its main limitations. If a meta-analysis includes studies that were designed with a high risk of bias or studies that have slightly different end points, the results will be less reliable or informative than if the analysis included only higher-quality studies or studies with the same end points. Meta-analyses can also amplify publication bias because they only include published studies, and negative studies are less likely to be submitted or published.

Key learning point: The advantages of meta-analysis are that it incorporates multiple analyses, combines information from randomized trials, and provides a numeric summary.

E) INCORRECT:

In this case scenario, the stated outcome of interest is weight loss; therefore, a meta-analysis with weight loss as the outcome of interest will be more relevant than one that looks at insulin sensitivity as the outcome of interest.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for follow-up shortly after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He has a long history of obesity, with a current BMI of 45. For the past 3 years, he has engaged in an exercise program and attempted to diet by restricting calories and following various supervised weight-loss programs. Although he lost some weight with these interventions, he quickly regained it. With his new diabetes diagnosis, both he and his parents are increasingly concerned about the effect of his weight on his health. They ask you whether bariatric surgery could provide a longer-lasting weight-loss solution and reverse his diabetes diagnosis.
In looking for answers to their question, you find a prospective, observational, multicenter cohort study that enrolled adults and adolescents with obesity who were about to undergo Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery. The participants were followed longitudinally with serial measurements of outcomes related to weight loss and to remission of comorbid conditions, such as diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.
The 5-year outcomes of that trial showed that adolescents seemed to derive similar benefits to adults, with maintenance of weight loss at 5 years.
What is a common limitation with this type of study design?

choices.text: A high likelihood of participant attrition or loss to follow-up over the study period
An inappropriate control group introducing bias
Participants differing in their ability to recall the exposure, leading to recall bias
A subset of eligible patients declining enrollment to avoid being randomized to a treatment arm they prefer to avoid
Outcome data that rely on measurements obtained during routine medical care

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies are observational studies that follow a predetermined group over time. They are useful in demonstrating the effect of interventions or exposures on outcomes, determining a sequence of events, and studying the effect of time on the group.

Because information about the exposure of interest is obtained close to the time of the actual exposure, the risk of recall bias is reduced. However, prospective cohort studies typically take place over long periods of time, which can be costly in terms of time and funding and can also lead to participant attrition or loss to follow-up.

Key learning point: One limitation of prospective cohort studies is the duration of involvement by study participants, which adds to the expense of the study and can lead to loss of follow-up data from participants.

B) INCORRECT:

Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. Individuals with a specific disease or outcome (cases) are compared to those without the disease or outcome (controls). This design may be prone to recall bias if participants are asked to retrospectively recall their exposure and may also be limited by an inappropriate choice of the control group.

C) INCORRECT:

Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. Individuals with a specific disease or outcome (cases) are compared to those without the disease or outcome (controls). This design may be prone to recall bias if participants are asked to retrospectively recall their exposure and may also be limited by an inappropriate choice of the control group. Recall bias may also affect other study designs such as retrospective cohort studies and cross-sectional studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Unlike in interventional studies, such as randomized controlled trials, cohort studies do not alter the participants’ exposure. The exposure is determined by other factors, and the investigator is simply following participants over time to assess the effect of the exposure on the outcome of interest.

E) INCORRECT:

Study procedures are often as rigorous in prospective cohort studies as they are in interventional studies, with study visits to obtain a uniform data set (rather than reliance on data obtained in routine clinical care only).

questions.text: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the total number of cases of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia in the United States using a national health survey of a nationally representative sample of US citizens conducted in 2012. The investigators ultimately found that a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection is associated with syphilis. This study is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The use of a healthcare survey to determine the prevalence of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia at a single point in time is consistent with a cross-sectional study. A cross-sectional study determines the prevalence of variables of interest simultaneously, at a specific point in time (snapshot study). It allows conclusions to be drawn about associations between two factors (genitourinary chlamydia and syphilis) but usually not about exposure-outcome or temporal relationships (e.g., it cannot show that genitourinary chlamydia infection precedes syphilis infection or vice versa).

See “Overview of descriptive studies” table.

Key learning point: A cross-sectional study assesses the prevalence of exposures and outcomes simultaneously at a single point in time, allowing for association but not causality or temporal relationships.
Image Description:

Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.

Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.

In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.

Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.

In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.

Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

B) INCORRECT:

In a meta-analysis, data from multiple studies is pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies and/or common effects among studies. The research group here conducted a single study.

C) INCORRECT:

A retrospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (here genitourinary chlamydia infection). A review of medical records of patients in both groups is then conducted to determine if the disease of interest (here syphilis) has developed. In this study, however, data was collected at a single point in time and not in a longitudinal study over time. Cohort studies are well-suited to calculate disease incidence but not prevalence.

D) INCORRECT:

A case series is a quantitative compilation of similar individual cases. This research group used a healthcare survey, a systemic collection of data, for their study.

E) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies are helpful for determining the presence of risk factors for (rare) diseases. It starts with two groups: one with the disease of interest (case group: syphilis), and one without the disease (control group: no syphilis). The risk of exposure to a risk factor of interest (e.g., genitourinary chlamydia infection) is then determined. Here, the research group looked at data at a single point in time.
questions.hint: This study design is analyzing prevalence data in individuals collected at a single point in time.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man contacts his health care provider one day after his wife is diagnosed with a viral infection. He inquires about the use of a medication he has read about, which is reportedly effective in preventing infections caused by the identified virus strain. He asks whether this medication would be appropriate for postexposure prophylaxis. Which of the following types of clinical studies is most appropriate to review in order to provide the patient with evidence-based guidance?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which compare different treatment options against each other (e.g., medication vs. placebo), are appropriate to ascertain the efficacy and safety of a treatment for a particular condition. RCTs establish causality through hypothesis testing; study participants are randomly allocated to either the new treatment/intervention group or the control group and subsequently evaluated for the outcome of interest. Randomization reduces bias and confounding and confers a high level of evidence to these studies. The highest level of evidence is attributed to systematic reviews with meta-analysis of RCTs, followed by individual RCTs.

See “Levels of evidence” table.
Image Description:

Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.

Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.

In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.

Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.

In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.

Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

B) INCORRECT:

In a case-control study, study participants are first selected from a population based on a given outcome – individuals with the outcome (e.g., infection with the new virus strain) are assigned to a comparison group, and those without it are assigned to a control group. The frequency of exposure to a modifier (e.g., medication use) is then analyzed for each group. Case-control studies can test a hypothesis and establish some degree of causal inference, so they can be used to devise a treatment strategy. However, case-control studies are observational, analytical studies that do not manipulate the modifier; other study designs have a higher level of evidence.

C) INCORRECT:

A case report is an observational study that describes the clinical course of a disease in a single patient case (e.g., one patient taking medication after exposure to the virus strain) and can help establish a hypothesis. However, case reports have limited generalizability and do not establish causality, because they do not test hypotheses. Therefore, case reports do not provide the best possible evidence for devising a treatment strategy.

D) INCORRECT:

In a prospective cohort study, individuals with similar characteristics are categorized into groups based on their exposure to a modifier (e.g., medication use), and these groups are followed over a period of time to determine the incidence of a given outcome (e.g., infection with the virus strain). Prospective cohort studies can test a hypothesis and establish a certain level of causal inference, so they can be used to devise treatment strategies. However, prospective cohort studies are observational, analytical studies that do not manipulate the modifier; other study designs have a higher level of evidence.

E) INCORRECT:

A case series report is an observational study that describes the clinical course of a disease by aggregating similar patient cases (e.g., several patients taking medication after exposure to the virus strain). Case series reports can help establish a hypothesis, but have limited generalizability and do not establish causality, as they do not test hypotheses. Therefore, case series reports do not provide the best possible evidence for devising a treatment strategy.
questions.hint: In order to provide an appropriate treatment recommendation, it is important to review studies that evaluate the effect of an intervention.

questions.text: A clinician working in gastroenterology is interested in the relationship between smoking and the incidence of Barrett esophagus. At a departmental grand rounds she recently attended, one of the presenters claimed that smokers are only at increased risk for Barrett esophagus in the presence of acid reflux. She decides to design a retrospective cohort study to investigate the association between smoking and Barrett esophagus. After comparing 400 smokers to 400 non-smokers identified via chart review, she finds that smokers were at increased risk of Barrett esophagus at the end of a 10-year follow-up period (RR = 1.82, p < 0.001). Among patients with a history of acid reflux, there was no relationship between smoking and Barrett esophagus (p = 0.52). Likewise, no relationship was found between smoking and Barrett esophagus among patients without a history of acid reflux (p = 0.48). The relative risk value of 1.82 in this study is best explained by which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stratification is a method of study design used to prevent confounding. The population is first divided/stratified by a particular characteristic (i.e., a possible confounding variable) and then randomized. However, this approach does not explain why the relationship between the variables (smoking and Barrett esophagus) does not hold when a third variable (acid reflux) is examined.

B) INCORRECT:

In epidemiology, matching is a method of study design used to prevent confounding. However, this approach does not explain why the relationship between the variables (smoking and Barrett esophagus) does not hold when a third variable (acid reflux) is examined.

C) CORRECT:

The results of this study are likely due to confounding. The correlation between smoking and Barrett esophagus is no longer statistically significant after stratification (controlling for acid reflux). Acid reflux is a confounder because it affects both the dependent variable/outcome (Barrett esophagus) and independent variable/exposure to a risk factor (smoking). Rather than a true association existing between smoking and Barrett esophagus, the results of this study suggest that the increased prevalence of acid reflux among smokers may explain the apparent association between smoking and Barrett esophagus in the unadjusted analysis. To minimize confounding during study design, stratification, randomization, and/or matching can be used. Good study design includes anticipating potential confounders.

D) INCORRECT:

It is certainly possible that the two groups in this study are not comparable because of selection bias. However, this would not explain why the significant association between smoking and Barrett esophagus disappeared when acid reflux was factored out.

E) INCORRECT:

The p-value < 0.05 (here: p < 0.001) indicates that the likelihood that the association between smoking and Barrett esophagus is just due to chance or random error is smaller than 5%. However, after looking at another risk factor (acid reflux), the significant association between smoking and Barrett esophagus disappears, indicating a different kind of error.
questions.hint: The relationship between smoking and Barrett esophagus changed after stratified analysis.

questions.text: A case-control study is conducted to investigate the association between phenytoin use in pregnant women with epilepsy and congenital malformations in their newborns. The odds ratio of congenital malformations in newborns born to women who were undergoing treatment with phenytoin is 1.74 (P = 0.02) compared to newborns of women who were not treated with phenytoin. Which of the following 95% confidence intervals is most likely reported for this association?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 0.56–1.88 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 0.56–1.88. Though this range contains the calculated odds ratio of 1.74, it also contains the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1) and is, therefore, not statistically significant (i.e., P ≥ 0.05).

B) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 0.83–2.19 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 0.83–2.19. Though this range contains the calculated odds ratio of 1.74, it also contains the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1) and is, therefore, not statistically significant (i.e., P ≥ 0.05).

C) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 0.36–0.94 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 0.36–0.94. Though this range does not contain the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1), it does not contain the calculated odds ratio of 1.74.

D) CORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 1.34–2.36 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 1.34–2.36 This range contains the calculated odds ratio of 1.74; in addition, it does not contain an odds ratio of 1 (i.e., the null hypothesis value) and is, therefore, statistically significant (i.e., P < 0.05).

E) INCORRECT:

A 95% confidence interval of 1.75–2.48 indicates that there is a 95% chance that the true odds ratio lies between 1.75–2.48. Though this range does not contain the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1), it does not contain the calculated odds ratio of 1.74.
questions.hint: A P value < 0.05 corresponds to a 95% confidence interval that does not contain the null hypothesis value (i.e., an odds ratio of 1). In this scenario, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in the odds of congenital malformations in newborns born to women who received phenytoin compared to those who did not.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman with stage IV ovarian cancer comes to the physician for follow-up after cytoreductive surgery and completion of first-line chemotherapy with bevacizumab, carboplatin, and paclitaxel. She currently has no evidence of disease and a normal cancer-antigen-125 level. The plan is to continue maintenance chemotherapy, and her oncologist reported that a new trial supported adding olaparib to the current standard of care, which is bevacizumab. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial comparing the addition of olaparib or placebo to maintenance chemotherapy with bevacizumab in ovarian cancer. The trial’s efficacy data were analyzed in the intention-to-treat population. Which of the following is the immediate effect of using the intention-to-treat population to analyze the efficacy data in this study?

choices.text: Reduced data loss due to loss of follow-up
Improved generalizability to a larger population
Most accurate estimate of the efficacy of the treatment under optimal conditions
Preservation of the balance of randomization
Inclusion of participants limited to those who received their allocated treatment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat analysis is an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not mitigate data loss due to loss of follow-up.

B) INCORRECT:

Improved generalizability to a larger population can be a downstream advantage of intention-to-treat analysis, as it reflects treatment efficacy in real-world settings. However, this is not the immediate effect of this analytical method.

C) INCORRECT:

Intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis includes patients who did not adhere to treatment, which can make the novel treatment appear less effective than it is. The converse of ITT analysis is per-protocol (PP) analysis, in which study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis. Using PP analysis improves the estimate of the effect of treatment under optimal conditions but increases selection bias.

D) CORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are designed to reduce as many differences as possible between the two groups being studied, so that any difference observed between the groups can truly be attributed to the intervention being studied. However, participants do not always fully follow the protocol they were assigned to; for example, they might discontinue the intervention because of adverse events, cross over to the alternative intervention, or not return for follow-up. In an intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis, all study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to (analyzed as-randomized), regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study. Thereby, ITT analysis preserves the benefits of the randomization, reduces selection bias, and better reflects real-world settings (where patients do not always follow the treatment plans laid out for them), but it may also underestimate the true efficacy of an intervention.

The converse of ITT analysis is per-protocol analysis, in which study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis.

E) INCORRECT:

In intention-to-treat analysis, all study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to, regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study.

questions.text: A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 12-hour history of fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and foul-smelling urine. A urinalysis is positive for white cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites. The physician prescribes a 10-day course of oral cefixime and discusses close follow-up with the family. One week later, the patient is afebrile, eating well, and in no distress. A voiding cystourethrogram shows grade 2 vesicoureteral reflux. The family asks how to proceed. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux. Which of the following statements about this study’s design is correct?

choices.text: The study design ensures that even adverse effects of prophylactic antibiotics can be identified.
The statistical analyses performed in this type of study are different from those performed in other study types.
This study is designed to optimize the ability to make inferences about the effect of prophylactic antibiotics on the outcome.
The study design allows the most accurate measurement of the outcome of urinary tract infections and renal scarring.
This study is designed to optimize generalizability of the results to all children with vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

B) INCORRECT:

The statistical analyses used for clinical trials are similar to those used in other study designs. Randomization in a clinical trial allows estimation of the causal effect, but the statistical approaches used are not different in this study design than in others.

C) CORRECT:

The primary advantage of RCTs is high internal validity so that a causal inference can be made about the intervention (in this case, prophylactic antibiotics) and the outcome (urinary tract infections and renal scarring). Random allocation to the treatment groups (which leads to balancing of potential confounders between the groups) and blinding allow the investigators to attribute any observed differences in the primary outcome between treatment groups to the intervention and not to other causes. Thus, the advantage of the study identified is that it allows the researchers to determine whether prophylactic antibiotics are beneficial in preventing urinary tract infections and scarring.

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

D) INCORRECT:

The accuracy of the outcome metric is not affected by the study design. It is determined by the manner in which the researchers are able to measure or determine the outcome. An accurate measure of the outcome is important for a clinical trial, but it is equally important for any other research study design.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.
questions.hint: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine well-child visit. The mother reports that she lives with her partner, who is a smoker. She asks about the health effects of household smoking on children, especially on the risk of developing childhood asthma. In literature search, the physician finds an observational study describing the effect of cigarette smoking on childhood health outcomes in 5000 children. An unadjusted analysis of the data from 10-year follow-up shows that childhood exposure to household tobacco smoke is associated with a high risk of developing childhood asthma. Which of the following strategies would have been appropriate for the researchers to use to address confounding in this study?

choices.text: Adjust the analysis for sex, socioeconomic class, and exposure to air pollution
Increase the follow-up time of the study
Increase the sample size of the study
Change the study design to a randomized controlled trial

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Confounders are factors that affect both the exposure and the outcome in a study. For example, in this study, a possible confounder is air pollution, which could be associated with both household tobacco smoke (the exposure of interest) and the development of childhood asthma (the outcome of interest). If this confounder is not properly accounted for, then the observed association between household tobacco smoke and childhood asthma could be incorrectly interpreted to signify causation. Researchers can address and reduce confounding during study design (by e.g., randomization, matching) and/or study analysis (by using e.g., stratified analysis, multiple regression analysis).

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing the follow-up time of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study. However, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how long the participants were followed.

C) INCORRECT:

Adjustment for multiplicity is an approach to handle performing many statistical tests in a single analysis, but it does not address confounding.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the sample size of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study. However, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how many participants were included.

E) INCORRECT:

One way to address confounders during study design is by choosing to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, there are scenarios in which RCTs are impractical or unethical, such as evaluating the long-term effects of household tobacco smoke exposure in children. In observational studies, the effects of confounding can be minimized during study design by restricting the inclusion criteria so that the study population is homogenous with respect to a particular variable (e.g., by including only a certain socioeconomic class).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office after receiving a new diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Genetic analysis showed that the cancer is Philadelphia chromosome positive (Ph+), and the physician is now deciding which chemotherapy regimen to initiate. She reviews the recently published results of a randomized controlled trial that compared a new chemotherapy agent with standard care in children with Ph+ ALL. The primary outcome was progression-free survival. Which of the following is the main question that this study was designed to address?

choices.text: Is the new chemotherapy agent better than standard care at improving progression-free survival in patients with ALL?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent, compared with standard care, on progression-free survival in children with Ph+ ALL?
What is the best chemotherapy agent for patients with Ph+ ALL?
Do patients with Ph+ ALL live longer if they are treated with the new chemotherapy agent?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent on progression-free survival in children with ALL?

questions.solution:

RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one). The design of RCTs ensures that intervention groups are treated the same except for the intervention that is being studied, and the process of randomization and blinding (if present) minimizes confounding and bias so that the effect of the treatment can be estimated. This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

C) INCORRECT:

Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever for the past 4 hours. He is approached about participating in a research study of patients being evaluated for appendicitis, and he consents. The goal of the study is to validate a new point-of-care test measuring “serum protein Y” to diagnose appendicitis in patients presenting with abdominal pain. The outcome of whether appendicitis was present will be established by validation based on experts’ retrospective review of the clinical, laboratory, and imaging data as well as histopathologic examination of the appendix in patients who undergo appendectomy. These data will be used to establish whether the test for “serum protein Y” may be useful in diagnosing appendicitis preoperatively. The patient is informed that participating in the study will not provide any benefit to himself but that the results may benefit future patients. During the patient’s evaluation, an abdominal CT scan reveals mild thickening of the appendix with signs of surrounding inflammation. He is scheduled for urgent surgical exploration of the appendix. As part of the study protocol, a research assistant obtains a drop of blood with a fingerstick. The result of the “serum protein Y” returns very low, which the investigators have hypothesized may indicate low risk for appendicitis. The research assistant enters the result into the study database for future analysis. The patient continues to await his surgery. At the current time, who of the following should the research assistant inform about the results of the experimental test?

choices.text: The principal investigator of the study
The principal investigator of the study, the surgeon, and the patient
