questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the office for follow-up shortly after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He has a long history of obesity, with a current BMI of 45. For the past 3 years, he has engaged in an exercise program and attempted to diet by restricting calories and following various supervised weight-loss programs. Although he lost some weight with these interventions, he quickly regained it. With his new diabetes diagnosis, both he and his parents are increasingly concerned about the effect of his weight on his health. They ask the physician whether bariatric surgery could provide a longer-lasting weight-loss solution and reverse his diabetes diagnosis. In looking for answers to their question, the physician finds a prospective, observational, multicenter cohort study that enrolled adults and adolescents with obesity who were about to undergo Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. The participants were followed longitudinally with serial measurements of outcomes related to weight loss and remission of comorbid conditions. The 5-year outcomes of that trial showed that adolescents seemed to derive similar benefits to adults, with maintenance of weight loss at 5 years. Which of the following is a common limitation with this type of study design?

choices.text: Outcome data that rely on measurements obtained during routine medical care
Participants differing in their ability to recall the exposure, leading to recall bias
A high likelihood of participant attrition over the study period
Eligible patients declining enrollment to avoid being randomized to a treatment arm they prefer to avoid
An inappropriate control group introducing bias

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Study procedures are often as rigorous in prospective cohort studies as they are in interventional studies, with study visits to obtain a uniform data set rather than reliance on data obtained in routine clinical care only.

B) INCORRECT:

Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. Individuals with a specific disease or outcome (cases) are compared to those without the disease or outcome (controls). This design may be prone to recall bias if participants are asked to retrospectively recall their exposure. Recall bias may also affect other study designs such as retrospective cohort studies and cross-sectional studies. In prospective cohort studies, however, the information about the exposure of interest is typically obtained close to the time of the actual exposure, which is why the risk of recall bias is reduced.

C) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies are observational studies that follow a predetermined group over time. They are useful in demonstrating the effect of interventions or exposures on outcomes, determining a sequence of events, and studying the effect of time on the group. Because information about the exposure of interest is obtained close to the time of the actual exposure, the risk of recall bias is reduced. However, prospective cohort studies typically take place over long periods of time, which can be costly in terms of time and funding and can also lead to participant attrition or loss to follow-up.

Loss to follow-up may cause attrition bias if the remaining participants differ significantly from those lost to follow-up, especially if the reason for the dropout is related to the outcome.

D) INCORRECT:

Unlike in interventional studies, such as randomized controlled trials, cohort studies do not alter the participants’ exposure. The exposure is determined by other factors, and the investigator is simply following participants over time to assess the effect of the exposure on the outcome of interest.

E) INCORRECT:

Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. In case-control studies, the study sample is selected according to having a disease or not, and then it is determined which participants were exposed to a risk factor. Controls are selected from the same source population and ideally have similar characteristics (e.g., gender, age) to the cases. Inappropriate choice of the control group can lead to confounding.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine visit. Her mother mentions that her previously healthy father, the child’s grandfather, was recently diagnosed with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The mother reports that she has been preoccupied with the diagnosis and has subsequently tried to limit her family’s exposure to potential carcinogens. She has read multiple media reports about exposure to plastics and the development of pancreatic cancer. She asks the physician about the carcinogenic potential of bisphenol A in the plastic containers she uses to pack and microwave lunches for her daughter. The physician decides to review the appropriate literature. Which of the following types of research studies would be most appropriate to answer this patient’s question?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A case series is a type of descriptive study that is used to report rare or novel associations between an exposure and an outcome. This type of study is useful for documenting rare clinical events but cannot provide analytical measures such as risk difference.

B) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies are a type of observational study in which population-level data are analyzed at a single point in time. Because of the descriptive nature of these studies, they cannot be used to estimate the risk difference or determine the temporal relationship between an exposure and an outcome.

C) INCORRECT:

Although crossover trials, in which patients are randomized to a series of exposures, can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

D) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are superior in the hierarchy of evidence because of their ability to limit bias. Although this type of study can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

E) CORRECT:

One study design that is best suited to investigate the link between environmental exposures and rare outcomes is a cohort study. In prospective cohort studies, groups of patients who do and do not have the exposure in question are followed to determine if they develop a defined outcome. This type of study provides a direct measure of risk difference (incidence in the exposed group minus incidence in the unexposed group). In this example, the exposed cohort would be those who had exposure to bisphenol A, and the outcome would be the development of pancreatic cancer.

An alternative way to address this question would be a case-control study. In this type of study, researchers enroll individuals who already have or do not have the outcome in question (in this case, pancreatic cancer). These individuals are then studied retrospectively to determine their exposures. This study design is subject to recall bias, which can limit the strength of the conclusions drawn.

questions.text: Investigators compare a new nutrition program with standard care to assess long-term effects on well-being. They employ a method that randomly allocates participants to either intervention. Which factor best explains why this study design is considered superior for determining causality?

choices.text: Detailed participant matching on baseline factors completely removes all confounding
Blinding study personnel eliminates bias by concealing the intervention from researchers
Comparing rates of outcomes across different populations ensures wide applicability
Chance-based group assignment minimizes confounding by evenly distributing variables across arms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Matching addresses only known and measured variables, while random allocation balances both measured and unmeasured confounders across groups. Matching cannot eliminate confounding from unidentified factors and is more prone to imbalances compared to randomization, which comprehensively equalizes potential confounders.

B) INCORRECT:

Blinding minimizes observer and performance biases but is not the primary factor for causal inference. The study's strength in determining causality lies in random allocation, which balances confounders between groups. Blinding reduces subjective outcome assessment but is secondary to randomization's role in establishing internal validity.

C) INCORRECT:

This statement pertains to external validity, or generalizability, rather than internal validity needed for causal inference. Random allocation minimizes confounding factors, ensuring observed differences are due to the intervention. Outcome comparisons across populations do not inherently control confounders, essential for establishing causality.

D) CORRECT:

Random allocation is a cornerstone of randomized controlled trials, providing the highest level of evidence for causality. It ensures that both known and unknown confounding variables are evenly distributed across intervention groups, reducing systematic bias. This method enhances internal validity by attributing differences in outcomes to the intervention rather than external factors, allowing for a more accurate assessment of the causal relationship between the nutrition program and well-being.

Key learning point: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) provide the highest level of evidence for establishing causality, such as the effect of exercise on quality of life, due to their design that minimizes bias and confounding.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and obesity presents for routine care. Despite nonpharmacologic and medical therapy, her weight and BMI have increased during the past 3 years. The physician is considering referring her for bariatric surgery to manage her weight. Before doing so, he reviews the literature and finds several studies with conflicting conclusions. Which of the following studies identified during the literature search would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in managing this patient’s weight?

choices.text: A retrospective observational study describing the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss
The randomized controlled trial with the largest number of participants comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
A metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
A systematic review of randomized controlled trials and observational studies describing the effect of gastric bypass surgery on weight loss
A metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on insulin sensitivity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An observational study does not benefit from the randomization process inherent in randomized controlled trials. Furthermore, a different type of study that involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies can provide a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study.

B) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions. However, there is a different type of study design with higher statistical power that can provide an even more precise estimate of effect than a single, large RCT.

C) CORRECT:

Metaanalysis is a method of collecting and analyzing data from multiple studies to create a numerical summary and estimate of effect. Metaanalysis provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more precise estimate of effect than a single study. It is therefore particularly useful when different studies yield different estimates of the overall effect of interest. Moreover, pooling studies together increases statistical power. Analyzing data from randomized controlled trials retains the benefits of randomization.

Metaanalysis is only as good as the data being analyzed, which is one of its main limitations. If a metaanalysis includes studies that were designed with a high risk of bias or studies that have slightly different end points, the results will be less reliable or informative than if the analysis included only higher-quality studies or studies with the same end points. Metaanalyses can also amplify publication bias because they only include published studies, and negative studies are less likely to be submitted or published.

D) INCORRECT:

A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a specific research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis of a metaanalysis if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. However, a comparison of the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

In this case scenario, the stated outcome of interest is weight loss; therefore, a metaanalysis with insulin sensitivity as the outcome of interest will be less relevant.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of a 1-month history of frequent regurgitation and irritability. He is diagnosed with infantile gastroesophageal reflux (GER). His parents ask about the prognosis of the condition. Which of the following study designs would be most likely to yield useful data on the long-term prognosis of a common condition such as infantile GER?

choices.text: Long-term follow-up of participants in a randomized controlled trial

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies represent the type of study best suited to elucidate the prognosis of a common disease process. At baseline, none of the subjects has developed the outcome of interest, but the assumption is that a sufficient number will develop it during the study to allow for useful statistical analysis. The data are collected prospectively to avoid recall bias. Disease conditions that have a low incidence are difficult to study with this design, because not many of the participants would develop the disease during the study.

B) INCORRECT:

In a long-term follow-up study of patients in a randomized controlled trial (i.e., experimental study), the outcome data may be unduly influenced by the intervention studied. In addition, the population of patients who meet the many criteria for enrollment in a clinical trial that focuses on a specific condition may not represent the broad population of patients with that condition.

C) INCORRECT:

A case series can provide data on patient outcomes, but it is hard to draw conclusions from this type of study because it often involves a small sample of patients selected in nonrandomized fashion (for example, a group of patients followed at a particular institution for a particular reason).

D) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies can offer valuable information about patients’ long-term outcomes, especially when the condition of interest is rare and may not be detected in a large cohort. However, the retrospective collection of data can bias the findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies evaluate disease characteristics at a specific point in time. This type of observational study does not adequately elucidate the prognosis of a condition.

questions.text: During rounds with medical students, an attending physician examines a 33-year-old man in the intensive care unit who suffered second-degree burns over 24% of his body-surface area. One of the students asks whether checking the patient’s procalcitonin levels would be useful to detect early signs of sepsis. Which of the following study designs would be most useful in determining the predictive value of procalcitonin levels for detecting sepsis in a burn patient?

choices.text: Case-control study evaluating procalcitonin levels in hospitalized burn patients who developed sepsis and those who did not
An animal study in which procalcitonin levels are measured in mice with and without sepsis
Prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
Metaanalysis of prospective cohort studies of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
Case series of 25 burn patients who developed sepsis, with graphs of daily procalcitonin levels for each patient

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies compare the characteristics of individuals who already have a particular disease (cases) with the characteristics of individuals who do not have that disease (controls). These studies are very useful for rare diseases, but the investigators do not follow patients over time and thus cannot calculate incidence. Although a case-control study comparing the procalcitonin levels among burn patients who developed sepsis with those who did not would be a valid design, it would be less informative and more prone to bias than study types that are higher on the hierarchy of evidence.

B) INCORRECT:

Animal studies are far less likely than observational human studies to provide clinically useful data.

C) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients whose procalcitonin levels were tracked over time could quantify the incidence of sepsis among burn patients and describe how trends in procalcitonin did or did not predict the development of sepsis. However, a single study of this type is limited by its sample size, the number of institutions involved, and other factors that may make the study population different from the population of all hospitalized burn patients.

D) CORRECT:

All clinical research studies are subject to both random and systematic error that can lead to incorrect conclusions about the answer to a research question. The hierarchy of evidence stipulates that different study designs have different inferential power and different likelihoods of systematic error. Randomized controlled trials are at the top of the hierarchy for most clinical questions, but are not always feasible. For observational studies, metaanalysis of cohort studies has the highest strength of evidence, followed by prospective cohort study, retrospective cohort study, case-control study, cross-sectional study, and case series.

A metaanalysis of prospective cohort studies has the advantage of effectively increasing the sample size (by including information from multiple studies or sources) and using statistical methods to pool the results. Although each study included in the metaanalysis may be subject to bias in one direction or another, the combination of study results is more likely to lead to an accurate approximation of a statistical association than any one study alone.

E) INCORRECT:

A case series is a descriptive study about a group of patients with the same disease or condition who all have the exposure of interest (in this case, measurement of procalcitonin levels). Although this type of study can be used to generate hypotheses, it does not include a comparison group, which makes drawing conclusions about causality very difficult.

questions.text: Researchers have postulated that intrauterine insults, possibly related to certain drugs taken during pregnancy, might be associated with a rare type of cancer that typically develops in the second decade of life. Which of the following types of studies is most appropriate and cost-effective for determining whether the postulated association is real?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Case-control studies are useful for evaluating relationships between rare outcomes and multiple past exposures during a long period of time. Given the retrospective study design and lack of intervention, case-control studies are relatively inexpensive to conduct compared with randomized controlled trials. The major challenges with conducting case-control studies are matching appropriate controls to the cases and preventing or minimizing recall bias.

B) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional surveys are best for establishing the prevalence of a disorder at a particular moment in time.

C) INCORRECT:

In a crossover study, patients serve as their own controls to limit confounding. This type of study is typically used to study the treatment effects of drugs.

D) INCORRECT:

In a prospective cohort study, researchers define a cohort of patients and then follow them to see who develops the outcome of interest. This study design would not be suitable to answer the question at hand in a timely, cost-effective fashion.

E) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are not ideal for studying exposures for which the outcome of interest takes a long time to develop.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is diagnosed with a rare subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis. During the diagnostic workup, she was found to have an ovarian teratoma. Her physician is curious whether ovarian teratoma is a risk factor for the development of anti-NMDA encephalitis. A causal relationship between this subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis and ovarian teratomas is suspected. The physician aims to identify patients with anti-NMDA encephalitis and subsequently evaluate them for the presence or a history of ovarian teratomas. Which of the following types of study design would be the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Case-control studies are well-suited for investigating conditions like uncommon subtypes of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, as they offer a cost-effective approach to examining rare outcomes or conditions with prolonged latency periods and their associated risk factors. By comparing affected individuals to a control group without anti-NMDA encephalitis, potential risk factors linked to disease development can be identified. The strength of association between a given risk factor and the disease is typically quantified using the odds ratio. In contrast to cohort studies, case-control studies begin by selecting individuals based on the presence or absence of the outcome of interest (in this case, anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis) and then retrospectively assess the prevalence of specific exposures or risk factors (e.g., ovarian teratomas) within each group.

On a side note, case-control studies have found an association between the occurrence of ovarian teratomas in young women and anti-NMDA encephalitis. Encephalitis is considered a paraneoplastic syndrome in these patients.

Key learning point: Case-control studies are well-suited for rare conditions because they identify subjects based on outcome and retrospectively compare prior exposures between cases and controls, using odds ratios to evaluate associations.
Image Description:

Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.

Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.

In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.

Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.

In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.

Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

B) INCORRECT:

A cross-sectional study can assess the prevalence of teratomas and anti-NMDA encephalitis at a single time point, but cannot clarify temporal relationships (e.g., whether ovarian teratomas precede the onset of anti-NMDA encephalitis).

C) INCORRECT:

A case series describes the clinical course of similar cases but does not allow drawing conclusions about causal relationships. At best, a hypothesis can be suggested based on several observed cases. Moreover, a case series would be very susceptible to selection bias because there are no comparator groups.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrospective cohort studies, which analyze existing data, can be used to study rare diseases. They begin by identifying the risk factor (e.g., ovarian teratoma) and then assessing the outcome (e.g., anti-NMDA encephalitis). However, since this researcher has already identified the outcome and wants to investigate associated risk factors, a retrospective cohort design is less suitable. Additionally, due to the low incidence of anti-NMDA encephalitis, finding a cohort of patients with ovarian teratomas and determining how many developed the encephalitis via chart review would be time-consuming and impractical.

E) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study would follow a large group of individuals over a period of time until they developed the outcome of interest (anti-NMDA encephalitis). Given that the outcome of this investigation is a rare subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis, conducting such a study would be both resource-intensive and time-consuming.
questions.hint: When exploring risk factors for an uncommon disease, enrolling individuals based on disease status and then examining their prior exposures provides an efficient strategy to investigate potential causal associations.

questions.text: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in Canada. The investigators examined the correlation between income and rates of syphilis in neighborhoods of Toronto, Vancouver, Montréal, and Calgary. Data on the annual number of notified syphilis cases in a neighborhood and the number of individuals in a neighborhood who are beneficiaries of welfare programs during the same time were provided by each city's health agency. Data on each neighborhood's total population for the same time could not be obtained and approximations from the last census were used. This study is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cross-sectional study determines the prevalence of variables of interest by gathering data at the level of individuals at a specific point in time (snapshot study). Here, the investigators gathered data on syphilis and income on a neighborhood-by-neighborhood basis, which is characteristic of a different type of study design.

B) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies are helpful for determining the presence of risk factors for (rare) diseases. They involve two groups of individuals: one with the disease of interest (case group: patients with syphilis), and one without the disease (control group: patients without syphilis). The risk of exposure to a risk factor of interest (e.g., low income) is then determined. Here, the research group collected data at the population level rather than looking at individual cases of exposure.

C) CORRECT:

Because the researchers used data from city health agencies to assess syphilis rates and neighborhood income levels, they conducted an ecological study. In this type of observational study, the units of observation are populations or groups—such as cities, countries, or socioeconomic strata—and data are analyzed in aggregate for exposures and outcomes. Ecological studies are well-suited for exploring correlational hypotheses at the group level but do not allow conclusions about individual risk (for example, the personal risk of developing syphilis based on income).

See “Overview of descriptive studies” table.

Key learning point: Ecological studies examine associations between exposures and outcomes using aggregate data at the group level.

D) INCORRECT:

Cohort studies are used to determine and compare the incidence of a disease in two groups of individuals. A retrospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (e.g., low income). A review of medical records of patients in both groups is then conducted to determine if the disease of interest (e.g., syphilis) has developed. In this study, however, data for syphilis and income were gathered from several city health agencies at the population level; no individual cases were assessed.

E) INCORRECT:

In a meta-analysis, data from multiple studies are pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies between and/or common effects among studies. Here, the research group conducted a single study.
questions.hint: This study gathers data on syphilis and income at the neighborhood level rather than from individuals.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) on cognitive performance in patients with Alzheimer disease. A cohort of 50 patients with mild Alzheimer disease were randomized 1:1 to either tDCS or sham tDCS (placebo) over the temporoparietal cortex. Both procedures were conducted so that patients experienced the same sensations while receiving treatment. After 2 weeks of treatment and neuropsychiatric testing to assess recognition memory and 1 week of observation during which no treatments were delivered, the treatment in each group was changed to the one used in the other group. Neuropsychiatric testing was subsequently repeated. Which of the following best describes the study design?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A case-control design is an observational study in which a particular risk factor (e.g., smoking) is retroactively assessed in two groups that are selected according to the presence/absence of a particular outcome (e.g., lung cancer). The investigator does not intervene in an observational study, unlike in the experimental study described here, where the participants received tDCS/sham tDCS.

B) CORRECT:

In a crossover study, every participant receives all the interventions but at different times and/or in a different sequence. In the study described in this vignette, all the participants sequentially received tDCS and sham tDCS (i.e., the groups crossed over). A washout period between treatments is commonly included in crossover studies to enable any effects of the first treatment to wear off prior to starting the sequential treatment. Crossover designs are best suited to study interventions with a temporary effect for chronic diseases with a stable state during the study period. They are not suitable for studying acute conditions or interventions with a permanent or long carry-over effect (e.g., vaccinations, surgery).

When compared to other RCT variants, the advantages of a crossover study design include a low risk of confounding bias, high recruitment rates (because each participant knows that they will be in the nonplacebo arm at some point), and increased statistical power (due to doubling of the sample size with the same number of participants). The disadvantages include a long study period (due to the crossover phase and the need for a washout period) and the resulting increase in the dropout rate.

Key learning point: In a crossover study, participants receive all interventions in varying sequences with washout periods to reduce confounding and increase statistical power, making it suitable for stable chronic conditions with temporary treatment effects.

C) INCORRECT:

In a pretest-posttest study design, data (e.g., a test score, a laboratory study) are collected before and after an intervention (e.g., a new teaching method, administration of a new drug) to study the effect of the intervention. All participants of a pretest-posttest study receive the same single intervention, unlike in this study, where both groups received both interventions in a different sequence.

D) INCORRECT:

In a parallel group design, participants are randomized into different groups (treatment vs. placebo) and remain within that group until the end of the study. The participants in the study here switched groups after a week to experience both interventions, so this is not a parallel group study.

E) INCORRECT:

In a meta-analysis, the results of multiple similar studies are pooled and analyzed in order to improve the statistical power of the results. The study described here is a single, experimental study.
questions.hint: In this variant of a randomized controlled trial (RCT), each participant serves as their own control.

questions.text: A group of researchers conducted a study to determine whether there is an association between folic acid supplementation before pregnancy and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in offspring. The researchers retrospectively surveyed 200 mothers of children diagnosed with ASD during the first 4 years of life and 200 mothers of children without developmental disorders. All participants were interviewed about their prenatal consumption of folic acid using standardized questionnaires. A 94% response rate was obtained from the surveys. The study ultimately found that folic acid supplementation was associated with lower rates of ASD in offspring (OR = 0.3, p < 0.01). Which of the following type of bias is most likely to have influenced these results?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

It is unlikely that survival bias is at play here. While it is possible that the children in the study have more severe disease than those whose mothers opted not to participate, it is not likely that this is because the true population of those with ASD had different rates of survival or resolution of disease.

B) INCORRECT:

It is unlikely that non-response bias influenced the results of the study, as the response rate was high (94%).

C) INCORRECT:

Length-time bias primarily occurs in screening studies rather than case-control studies. It influences the observed survival time of individuals with the disease, but does not affect the comparison of exposures between those with and without the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This study used standardized questionnaires, making interviewer bias unlikely. There is no indication that there were any differences in the way that the questionnaires here were administered to the two groups.

E) CORRECT:

Recall bias is a major concern in case-control studies because participants with a specific outcome may remember past exposures more clearly or in greater detail than those without the outcome. This differential recall can result in exposure misclassification and potentially create false associations between the exposure and the outcome.

Key learning point: Recall bias in retrospective studies occurs when participants with the outcome remember exposures differently than controls.
questions.hint: A significant period (4 years) has passed between the prenatal exposure being studied here and the administration of the questionnaire.

questions.text: An investigator conducts a case-control study to evaluate the relationship between Alzheimer disease (AD) and benzodiazepine use in patients older than 65 years of age. Three hundred patients of advanced age with Alzheimer disease are recruited from assisted-living facilities throughout the Toronto metropolitan area, and their rates of benzodiazepine use are compared to 300 controls. Which of the following describes a patient who would be appropriate for the study's control group?

choices.text: An 80-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an independent-living community.
A 68-year-old man with hypercholesterolemia, mild benign prostate hyperplasia, and poorly-controlled diabetes who is hospitalized for pneumonia.
A 73-year-old woman with coronary artery disease who was recently discharged to an assisted-living facility from the hospital after a stroke.
A 64-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an assisted-living facility.
An 86-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an assisted-living facility.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This man comes from a different source population (a community center in an independent-living community, not an assisted-living facility), which poses a risk for selection bias. Thus, he is not an appropriate candidate for the control group.

B) INCORRECT:

Selecting an individual who is hospitalized poses a risk for Berkson bias because this man could have an increased risk of benzodiazepine exposure, which distorts the odds ratio. Thus, he is not an appropriate candidate for the control group.

C) INCORRECT:

Selecting an individual with a recent history of hospitalization poses a risk for Berkson bias because this woman could have an increased risk of benzodiazepine exposure, which distorts the odds ratio. Moreover, this woman has a comorbid condition (stroke) that might affect her cognitive status. Thus, she is not an appropriate candidate for the control group.

D) INCORRECT:

This man's age is outside the age of interest (> 65 years) for this study. Thus, he is not an appropriate candidate for the control group.

E) CORRECT:

Since individuals > 65 years of age residing in assisted-living facilities with AD are selected for the case group, the control group should consist of individuals > 65 years in the same setting with no history of AD. The case and control groups should be drawn from the same target population and matched to ensure similar baseline characteristics, apart from the exposure and outcome. To assess the adequacy of matching, investigators should gather detailed information on participant characteristics (e.g., age, sex, and comorbidities).

Key learning point: Controls in case-control studies should be free of the disease, drawn from the same source population as cases, and matched on relevant baseline characteristics to avoid confounding and selection bias.
questions.hint: In analytical observational studies (e.g., case-control), specific steps should be taken during the study design phase to minimize selection and confounding bias.

questions.text: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in Canada. The investigators examined the total number of cases of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia in Canada using a national health survey of a nationally representative sample of Canadian citizens conducted in 2012. The investigators ultimately found that a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection is associated with syphilis. This design is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The use of a healthcare survey to determine the prevalence of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia at a single point in time is consistent with a cross-sectional study. A cross-sectional study determines the prevalence of variables of interest simultaneously, at a specific point in time (snapshot study). It allows conclusions to be drawn about associations between two factors (genitourinary chlamydia and syphilis) but usually not about exposure-outcome or temporal relationships (i.e., it cannot show that genitourinary chlamydia infection precedes syphilis infection or vice versa).

See “Overview of descriptive studies” table.

Key learning point: A cross-sectional study measures the prevalence of health conditions at a single point in time, enabling assessment of associations between factors but not establishing temporal relationships or causality.
Image Description:

Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.

Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.

In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.

Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.

In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.

Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

B) INCORRECT:

A case series is a descriptive compilation of similar individual cases, often used to identify patterns or generate hypotheses. This research group used a healthcare survey, a systematic collection of data, for their study.

C) INCORRECT:

A retrospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (here genitourinary chlamydia infection). A review of medical records of patients in both groups is then conducted to determine if the disease of interest (here syphilis) has developed. In this study, however, data was collected at a single point in time and not in a longitudinal study over time. Cohort studies are well-suited to calculate disease incidence but not prevalence.

D) INCORRECT:

In a meta-analysis, data from multiple studies is pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies and/or common effects among studies. The research group here conducted a single study.

E) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies are helpful for determining the presence of risk factors for (rare) diseases. It starts with two groups: one with the disease of interest (case group: syphilis), and one without the disease (control group: no syphilis). The odds of exposure to a risk factor of interest (e.g., genitourinary chlamydia infection) are then determined. Here, the research group looked at data at a single point in time.
questions.hint: This study design analyzes prevalence data in individuals collected at a single point in time.

questions.text: In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux. Which of the following statements about this study’s design is correct?

choices.text: This study is designed to optimize generalizability of the results to all children with vesicoureteral reflux.
This study is designed to optimize the ability to make inferences about the effect of prophylactic antibiotics on the outcome.
The statistical analyses performed in this type of study are different from those performed in other study types.
The study design ensures that rare adverse effects of prophylactic antibiotics can be identified.
The study design allows the most accurate measurement of the outcome of urinary tract infections and renal scarring.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

B) CORRECT:

The primary advantage of RCTs is high internal validity so that a causal inference can be made about the intervention (in this case, prophylactic antibiotics) and the outcome (urinary tract infections and renal scarring). Random allocation to the treatment groups (which leads to balancing of potential confounders between the groups) and blinding allow the investigators to attribute any observed differences in the primary outcome between treatment groups to the intervention and not to other causes. Thus, the advantage of the study identified is that it allows the researchers to determine whether prophylactic antibiotics are beneficial in preventing urinary tract infections and scarring.

Patients who sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult (limited external validity). RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

Key learning point: Randomized controlled trials strengthen internal validity and minimize confounding, but their findings may have limited generalizability to broader populations.

C) INCORRECT:

The statistical analyses used in clinical trials are similar to those applied in other study designs. Although clinical trials incorporate randomization, the statistical methods themselves do not differ from those used in other types of studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials effectively detect common adverse effects due to their controlled settings and systematic monitoring. However, their limited sample sizes and follow-up durations make them less suitable for identifying rare or long-term adverse events, which are better captured by larger observational studies.

E) INCORRECT:

The accuracy of the outcome metric is not affected by the study design. It is determined by the manner in which the researchers are able to measure or determine the outcome. An accurate measure of the outcome is important for a clinical trial, but it is equally important for any other research study design.
questions.hint: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions.

questions.text: In literature search, the physician finds an observational study describing the effect of cigarette smoking on childhood health outcomes in 5000 children. An unadjusted analysis of the data from 10-year follow-up shows that childhood exposure to household tobacco smoke is associated with a high risk of developing childhood asthma. Which of the following strategies would have been appropriate for the researchers to use to address confounding in this study?

choices.text: Increase the sample size of the study.
Adjust the analysis for sex and exposure to air pollution.
Change the study design to a randomized controlled trial.
Increase the follow-up time of the study.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing the sample size of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study. However, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how many participants were included.

B) CORRECT:

Confounders are factors that affect both the exposure and the outcome in a study, but are not in the causal pathway. For example, in this study, a possible confounder is air pollution, which could be associated with both household tobacco smoke (the exposure of interest) and the development of childhood asthma (the outcome of interest). If this confounder is not properly accounted for, then the observed association between household tobacco smoke and childhood asthma could be incorrectly interpreted to signify causation. Researchers can address and reduce confounding during study design (e.g., through randomization, matching) and/or study analysis (e.g., stratified analysis, multiple regression analysis).

Key learning point: Confounding can be reduced by adjusting for variables that influence both the exposure and outcome, using stratified or multiple regression analysis, or employing design methods such as randomization and matching.

C) INCORRECT:

One way to address confounders during study design is by choosing to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, there are scenarios in which RCTs are impractical or unethical, such as evaluating the long-term effects of household tobacco smoke exposure in children.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the follow-up time of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study. However, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how long the participants were followed.

E) INCORRECT:

Adjustment for multiplicity is a statistical approach to control for type I errors when multiple statistical tests are used in a single analysis, but it does not address confounding.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office after receiving a new diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Genetic analysis showed that the cancer is Philadelphia chromosome positive (Ph+), and the physician is now deciding which chemotherapy regimen to initiate. She reviews the recently published results of a randomized controlled trial that compared a new chemotherapy agent with standard care in children with Ph+ ALL. The primary outcome was progression-free survival. Which of the following is the main question that this study was designed to address?

choices.text: What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent, compared with standard care, on progression-free survival in children with Ph+ ALL?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent on progression-free survival in children with ALL?
What is the best chemotherapy agent for patients with Ph+ ALL?
Do patients with Ph+ ALL live longer if they are treated with the new chemotherapy agent?
Is the new chemotherapy agent better than standard care at improving progression-free survival in patients with ALL?

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

RCTs are considered the gold standard for testing interventions because they can demonstrate causality between an intervention and an outcome. The design of RCTs ensures that intervention groups are treated the same except for the intervention that is being studied, and the process of randomization and blinding (if present) minimizes confounding and bias so that the effect of the treatment can be estimated. RCTs attempt to isolate the intervention so that any effects on the outcome are solely attributed to the intervention instead of other factors. This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

Key learning point: Randomized controlled trials determine the causal effect of an intervention on a predefined outcome in a specific population, providing high internal validity but limiting generalizability to other populations or outcomes.

B) INCORRECT:

In RCTs, the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population; in this case, the results would not apply to all children with ALL, and only to the measured outcome. This type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

C) INCORRECT:

RCTs cannot directly account for multifactorial effects that are not under study and thus cannot determine which treatment is best on balance.

D) INCORRECT:

RCTs cannot directly account for multifactorial effects that are difficult to measure and thus cannot determine which treatment is best on balance.

E) INCORRECT:

RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one). This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL) and only on the measured outcome. Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.
questions.hint: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention or treatment on a selected population.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine visit. Her mother mentions that her previously healthy father, the child’s grandfather, was recently diagnosed with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The mother reports that she has been preoccupied with the diagnosis and has subsequently tried to limit her family’s exposure to potential carcinogens. She has read multiple media reports about exposure to plastics and the development of pancreatic cancer. She asks the physician about the carcinogenic potential of bisphenol A in the plastic containers she uses to pack and microwave lunches for her daughter. The physician decides to review the appropriate literature. Which of the following types of research studies would be most appropriate to answer this patient’s question?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies are a type of observational study in which population-level data are analyzed at a single point in time. Because of the descriptive nature of these studies, they cannot be used to estimate the risk difference or determine the temporal relationship between an exposure and an outcome.

B) CORRECT:

One study design that is suited to investigate the link between environmental exposures and rare outcomes is a cohort study. In prospective cohort studies, groups of patients who do and do not have the exposure in question are followed to determine if they develop a defined outcome. This type of study provides a direct measure of risk difference (incidence in the exposed group minus incidence in the unexposed group). In this example, the exposed cohort would be those who had exposure to bisphenol A, and the outcome would be the development of pancreatic cancer.

An alternative way to address this question would be a case-control study. In this type of study, researchers enroll individuals who already have or do not have the outcome in question (in this case, pancreatic cancer). These individuals are then studied retrospectively to determine their exposures. This study design is subject to recall bias, which can limit the strength of the conclusions drawn.

Key learning point: Prospective cohort studies are the most appropriate design to evaluate potential causal relationships between environmental exposures and rare disease outcomes, as they enable measurement of incidence and risk while minimizing recall bias.

C) INCORRECT:

Although crossover trials, in which patients are randomized to a series of exposures, can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

D) INCORRECT:

A case series is a type of descriptive study that is used to report rare or novel associations between an exposure and an outcome. This type of study is useful for documenting rare clinical events, but cannot provide analytical measures such as relative risk and risk difference.

E) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are superior in the hierarchy of evidence because of their ability to limit bias. Although this type of study can be used to determine risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and obesity presents for routine care. Despite nonpharmacologic and medical therapy, her weight and BMI have increased during the past 3 years. The physician is considering referring her for bariatric surgery to manage her weight. Before doing so, he reviews the literature and finds several studies with conflicting conclusions. Which of the following studies identified during the literature search would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in managing this patient’s weight?

choices.text: The randomized controlled trial with the largest number of participants comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss.
A metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on insulin sensitivity.
A retrospective observational study describing the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss.
A metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss.
A systematic review of randomized controlled trials and observational studies describing the effect of gastric bypass surgery on weight loss.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions. However, there is a different type of study design with higher statistical power that can provide an even more precise estimate of effect than a single, large RCT.

B) INCORRECT:

In this case scenario, the stated outcome of interest is weight loss; therefore, a metaanalysis with insulin sensitivity as the outcome of interest will not answer the research question.

C) INCORRECT:

An observational study does not benefit from the randomization process inherent in randomized controlled trials. Furthermore, a different type of study that involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies can provide a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study.

D) CORRECT:

Metaanalysis is a method of collecting and analyzing data from multiple studies to create a numerical summary and estimate of effect. Metaanalysis provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more precise estimate of effect than a single study. It is therefore particularly useful when different studies yield different estimates of the overall effect of interest. Moreover, pooling studies together increases statistical power. Analyzing data from randomized controlled trials retains the benefits of randomization.

Metaanalyses are limited by the quality of the included studies. When studies with a high risk of bias or varying endpoints are combined, the overall results become less reliable and less informative compared to analyses including only high-quality studies with consistent endpoints. Additionally, metaanalyses may amplify publication bias since they typically include only published studies, and studies with negative results are less likely to be published.

Key learning point: Metaanalyses of randomized controlled trials provide precise, reproducible effect estimates and increased statistical power to resolve conflicting findings, but their reliability depends on the methodological quality, consistency of outcomes, and potential publication bias of the included studies.

E) INCORRECT:

A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a specific research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis for another study if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. However, a comparison of the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in this patient.
questions.hint: In clinical decision making, give greater weight to evidence from study designs ranked highest in the hierarchy of evidence.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of a 1-month history of frequent regurgitation and irritability. He is diagnosed with infantile gastroesophageal reflux (GER). His parents ask about the prognosis of the condition. Which of the following study designs would be most likely to yield useful data on the long-term prognosis of a common condition such as infantile GER?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies can offer valuable information about patients’ long-term outcomes, especially when the condition of interest is rare and may not be detected in a large cohort. However, the retrospective collection of data can bias the findings.

B) INCORRECT:

A case series can provide data on patient outcomes, but it is hard to draw conclusions from this type of study because it often involves a small sample of patients selected in nonrandomized fashion (for example, a group of patients followed at a particular institution for a particular reason).

C) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies evaluate disease characteristics at a specific point in time. This type of observational study does not adequately elucidate the prognosis of a condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials (i.e., experimental studies) typically compare an intervention or treatment, and the outcome data may be unduly influenced by the intervention studied. In addition, the population of patients who meet the many criteria for enrollment in a clinical trial that focuses on a specific condition may not represent the broad population of patients with that condition.

E) CORRECT:

Prospective cohort studies represent the type of study best suited to elucidate the prognosis of a common disease process. At baseline, none of the subjects has developed the outcome of interest, but the assumption is that a sufficient number will develop it during the study to allow for useful statistical analysis. The data are collected prospectively to avoid recall bias. Outcomes that have a low incidence are difficult to study with this design, because not many of the participants would develop the outcome during the study.

Key learning point: Prospective cohort studies are ideal for assessing the long-term outcomes of common conditions.
questions.hint: Following patients longitudinally from diagnosis with regular, standardized outcome assessments yields the most reliable long-term prognostic data.

questions.text: During rounds with medical students, an attending physician examines a 33-year-old man in the intensive care unit who suffered second-degree burns over 24% of his body-surface area. One of the students asks whether checking the patient’s procalcitonin levels would be useful to detect early signs of sepsis. Which of the following study designs would be most useful in determining the predictive value of procalcitonin levels for detecting sepsis in a burn patient?

choices.text: Case-control study evaluating procalcitonin levels in hospitalized burn patients who developed sepsis and those who did not.
An systematic review of animal studies in which procalcitonin levels are measured in mice with and without sepsis.
Case series of 25 burn patients who developed sepsis, with graphs of daily procalcitonin levels for each patient.
Metaanalysis of prospective cohort studies of hospitalized burn patients who had daily procalcitonin levels checked while being monitored for sepsis.
Prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Case-control studies compare the characteristics of individuals who already have a particular disease (cases) with the characteristics of individuals who do not have that disease (controls). These studies are very useful for rare diseases, but the investigators do not follow patients over time and thus cannot calculate incidence. Although a case-control study comparing the procalcitonin levels among burn patients who developed sepsis with those who did not would be a valid design, it would be less informative and more prone to bias than study types that are higher on the hierarchy of evidence.

B) INCORRECT:

Animal studies are far less likely than observational human studies to provide clinically useful data. Data from these studies cannot be used to make inferences about the human population.

C) INCORRECT:

A case series is a descriptive study about a group of patients with the same disease or condition who all have the exposure of interest (in this case, measurement of procalcitonin levels). Although this type of study can be used to generate hypotheses, it does not include a comparison group, which makes drawing conclusions about causality very difficult.

D) CORRECT:

All clinical research studies are subject to both random and systematic error that can lead to incorrect conclusions about the answer to a research question. The hierarchy of evidence stipulates that different study designs have different inferential statistical power and different likelihoods of systematic error. Randomized controlled trials are at the top of the hierarchy for most clinical questions but are not always feasible. For observational studies, metaanalysis of cohort studies has the highest strength of evidence, followed by prospective cohort study, retrospective cohort study, case-control study, cross-sectional study, and case series.

A metaanalysis of prospective cohort studies has the advantage of effectively increasing the sample size (by including information from multiple studies or sources) and using statistical methods to pool the results. Although each study included in the metaanalysis may be subject to bias in one direction or another, the combination of study results is more likely to lead to an accurate approximation of a statistical association than any one study alone.

Key learning point: Metaanalyses of cohort studies provide the highest level of evidence among observational designs by increasing sample size and reducing random error, making them useful when randomized controlled trials are not feasible.

E) INCORRECT:

A prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients whose procalcitonin levels were tracked over time could quantify the incidence of sepsis among burn patients and describe how trends in procalcitonin did or did not predict the development of sepsis. However, a single study of this type is limited by its sample size, the number of institutions involved, and other factors that may make the study population different from the population of all hospitalized burn patients.

questions.text: Researchers have postulated that intrauterine insults, possibly related to certain drugs taken during pregnancy, might be associated with a rare type of cancer that typically develops in the second decade of life. Which of the following types of studies is most appropriate and cost-effective for determining whether the postulated association is real?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a prospective cohort study, researchers define a cohort of patients and then follow them to see who develops the outcome of interest. This study design is not suitable for rare outcomes and would not be the most efficient or cost-effective way to answer the question.

B) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are not ideal for studying exposures for which the outcome of interest takes a long time to develop, as they are expensive and resource-intensive. In this scenario, an RCT would also not be the most ethical choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional surveys are best for establishing the prevalence of a disorder at a particular moment in time. This type of study cannot be used to infer causality or analyze associations.

D) CORRECT:

Case-control studies are useful for evaluating relationships between rare outcomes and multiple past exposures during a long period of time. Given the retrospective study design and lack of intervention, case-control studies are relatively inexpensive to conduct compared with randomized controlled trials. The major challenges with conducting case-control studies are matching appropriate controls to the cases and preventing or minimizing recall bias.

Key learning point: Case-control studies are cost-effective retrospective designs that are ideal for studying rare outcomes and multiple past exposures, although they require careful selection of controls and strategies to minimize recall bias.

E) INCORRECT:

In a crossover study, patients serve as their own controls to limit confounding. This type of study is typically used to study the treatment effects of drugs that do not have lasting effects. A crossover study would not be suitable or ethical for this scenario.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In case-control studies, researchers select patients with (cases) and without the outcome of interest (control group). In this study, the outcome of interest is interstitial lung disease. This study design allows odds ratios to be determined, i.e. the odds of developing interstitial lung disease dependent on exposure to the fire retardant chemical. Case-control studies are retrospective studies and are prone to recall bias.
Image Description:

Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.

Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.

In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.

Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.

In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.

Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

B) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies analyze data from a representative subset of a population at a specific point in time and can be used to determine prevalence or risk factors for a disease. Because this study design selects individuals based on the presence of a disease, it is not representative of the population, and therefore, not a cross-sectional study.

C) INCORRECT:

Case series are a series of reports on similar cases of a disease or exposure (i.e., to a drug). Unlike the study described here, case series do not use a matched comparative group (i.e., control group) in their design.

D) INCORRECT:

For retrospective cohort studies individuals are selected based on exposure and then it is observed if these individuals developed a specific disease. Because this study selected patients based on their known outcomes, it is not a cohort study.

E) INCORRECT:

In a randomized controlled trial, participants are prospectively selected and randomly assigned to control or treatment groups. Because this study retroactively selects participants and does not have an intervention of interest, it is not a randomized controlled trial.
questions.hint: This study identifies groups of people with and without the disease of interest, and then compares the presence of risk factors between these two groups.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the relationship between suicide and unemployment using data from a national health registry that encompasses 10,000 people who died by suicide, as well as 100,000 matched controls. The investigator finds that unemployment was associated with an increased risk of death by suicide (odds ratio = 3.02; p < 0.001). Among patients with a significant psychiatric history, there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment (p = 0.282). Likewise, no relationship was found between the two variables among patients without a psychiatric history (p = 0.32). These results are best explained by which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In epidemiology, matching is a study design method to reduce bias due to confounding. It is often used in case-control studies, as it is used here, to control for known confounders. Matching does not explain why the association between suicide and unemployment was no longer significant in the stratified analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Selection bias occurs if the study population does not reflect the target population. For example, it could have occurred here if the study had only recruited participants who owned firearms but then applied the results to a population where the prevalence of gun ownership was low. Selection bias does not explain why the association between suicide and unemployment was no longer significant in the stratified analysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Observer bias occurs when the measurement of a variable is influenced by the experimenter's knowledge or expectations; there is no evidence to suggest that the different odds ratios from the crude analysis and the stratified analysis were influenced by the experimenter.

D) INCORRECT:

Effect modification occurs when the relationship between an exposure and an outcome differs in the presence and absence of a third variable. When a stratified analysis is conducted, the stratum-specific effects will be different from each other. Here, the stratum-specific effects are the same: there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment in the group with a psychiatric history or the group without a psychiatric history.

E) INCORRECT:

Stratification is an analytical tool in which a group is divided into subgroups to determine if a relationship that is true for the entire group holds within each of the subgroups. It is the technique that was used here to determine that the crude analysis odds ratios differed from the stratum-specific odds ratios. However, stratification does not explain why odds ratios differed.

F) CORRECT:

Confounding may occur when the relationship between an exposure and an outcome is distorted by the effect of a third variable that has an association with both the exposure and the outcome. Here, the crude analysis showed a significant relationship between suicide and unemployment. However, when the sample was stratified by psychiatric history, there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment in the group with a psychiatric history or the group without a psychiatric history. Because a psychiatric history is associated with both unemployment and suicide, it is a potential confounder that may account for the observed results in the crude analysis.

To minimize confounding during study design, stratification, randomization, and/or matching can be used. Good study design includes anticipating potential confounders.
questions.hint: Upon stratifying for psychiatric history, the relationship between suicide and unemployment has changed such that it is no longer significant for both groups.
